headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Francine and I am your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to the host for
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Francine and I am your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to the host for today, Mr. Jay Wilson, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Francine, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our fourth quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projection
componenttext: Thank you, Francine, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our fourth quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements. With me today are John Hess, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; Greg Hill, President, Worldwide Exploration and Production; and John Rielly, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. I will now turn the call over to John Hess.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Welcome to our Fourth Quarter Conference Call. I would like to review key achievements of 2009 and provide some guidance for 2010. Greg Hill will then discuss our Exploration and Production business, and John Rielly will review our financi
componenttext: Thank you, Jay. Welcome to our Fourth Quarter Conference Call. I would like to review key achievements of 2009 and provide some guidance for 2010. Greg Hill will then discuss our Exploration and Production business, and John Rielly will review our financial results. Corporate net income for the full year 2009 was $740 million. Exploration and Production earned $1.04 billion, and Marketing and Refining earned $127 million. While our earnings were down versus the previous year, our results reflected strong financial performance, increasing crude low prices throughout 2009 and successful cost reduction efforts.In terms of our 2010 capital and exploratory program, we are revising our budget to $4.1 billion from $3.9 billion. This increase of $200 million is the result of the strategic asset trade with Shell announced in December, in which we will assume Shell's interest in the Valhall and Hod fields in Norway in exchange for Hess' interest in the Clair field in the United Kingdom and all of Hess's interest in Gabon. The transaction is anticipated to close in the first quarter and be effective January 1, 2010.As another step to improve our portfolio, we completed the sale earlier this month of our interest in Jambi Merang in Indonesia receiving proceeds of $180 million. As in previous years, substantially all of our 2010 spending will be targeted to exploration and production with $2.4 billion budgeted for production operations, $800 million for developments and $850 million for exploration.With regard to exploration and production, in 2009, we replaced 103% of production at an FD&A cost of about $20 per barrel of oil equivalent. At year end, our approved reserves stood at $1.44 billion barrels of oil equivalent and our reserve life was 9.5 years.In 2009, we increased crude oil and natural gas production 7% to 408,000 barrel equivalent of oil equivalent per day. In 2010, we forecast that crude oil and natural gas production will average between 400,000 and 410,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This forecast includes a net reduction of about 3,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day resulting from the strategic asset trade with Shell. With regard to developments, the Shenzi Field in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico in which Hess has a 30% interest, commence production in March and achieved a net rate of about $40,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day during the second half of 2009.We also sanctioned our Bakken Shale development in North Dakota. We plan to build up to a 10-rate program our next 18 months and invest about $1 billion per year over the next five years. As a result, we expect net production to increase from 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day currently to 80,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2015. In exploration we have continued success at 100%-owned, WA-390-P block at offshore Australia, where in 2009 we drilled seven was, six of which were natural gas discoveries. In Libya, we successfully flow tested the A1 discovery well on our 100% owned Area 54 license, and subsequently drilled and successfully flow tested it down to appraisal well.With regard to Marketing and Refining, our full-year 2009 financial results were lower than 2008, as the weak economy continue to have a negative impact on our business. Our HOVENSA joint venture refinery experienced losses as a result of significantly lower distillate crack spreads and narrower light-heavy crude low differentials.In retail marketing, our financial results were adversely affected by lower gasoline volumes, which were 3% in the last year and weaker margins, partially offset by higher convenience sources which were up nearly 11% from last year. In Energy Marketing, we generated stronger financial results, and increased sales of fuel oil and electricity.In 2009, we maintained a strong financial position in the face of a difficult economic environment. Our debt-to-capitalization ratio at the year end was 24.8%, a slight increase over 2008. Our liquidity was enhanced by the February 2009 issuance of $1 billion of 10-year notes and $250 million of five-year notes to reduce short-term debt. Also in the fourth quarter of 2009, we refinanced notes due in 2011 by issuing $750 million of 30-year bonds.We are pleased with our performance during 2009, despite a challenging and volatile year. We remain committed to our strategy of investing to profitably grow our reserves and production on a sustainable basis. We are extremely excited about our future investment opportunities which we believe will create long-term value for our shareholders. I will now turn the call over to Greg Hill.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Let me begin with production. In 2009, crude oil and natural gas production averaged 408,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was up 7% versus 2008. Production growth was underpinned by strong performance from the Shenzi Field in
componenttext: Thank you, John. Let me begin with production. In 2009, crude oil and natural gas production averaged 408,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was up 7% versus 2008. Production growth was underpinned by strong performance from the Shenzi Field in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, a full-year Phase II natural gas sales for the Malaysia-Thailand joint development area, and overall solid operating performance. In 2009, we had improved reserves of 157 million barrels of oil equivalent at an FD&A cost of about $20 per barrel of oil equivalent, yielding a replacement ratio of 103% and an R/P ratio of 9.5, a good result considering the capital spending reductions we made and our strong production growth in 2009. Including this year's results, our five-year average reserve replacement ratio is 162%, and our average FD&A cost is about $16 per barrel of oil equivalent. In December, we announced a strategic asset trade with Shell that provides us with an opportunity to consolidate our portfolio and double our interest in the Valhall and Hod fields in Norway, which are long-lived producing assets with significant reserves and upside potential, which will further support our long-term objective of profitably growing our reserves and production.Turning to our capital program for 2010, we plan to invest nearly $1 billion in the Bakken Oil Plant in North Dakota, where we hold more than 500,000 net acres. We expect our average rig count to increase from three in 2009 to 10 in 2011. At Pony in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, we plan to drill an additional appraisal well and anticipate unitization of Pony and Knotty Head in 2010, followed by a project sanction in 2011. The remainder of our capital program will focus on continued investment in a number of our core assets, including Shenzi, fields redevelopment at Valhall, an additional development drilling in Equatorial Guinea, the Malaysia-Thailand JDA and Pengka in Indonesia. Turning to exploration, in Australia, as a result of the 2009 drilling program on a 100% owned Western Australia 390-P license, we have now drilled 11 of the 16 commitment wells on the block and have had nine discoveries. We plan to drill additional five commitment wells during the first half of 2010, and are considering further appraisal wells. At the same time, we are continuing discussions regarding commercialization. Also at the Western Australia 404-P license, in  which half of the 50% interest, the operator, Woodside, will drill eight wells during 2010. Earlier this week, the operator announced that the first of these wells, Noblige-1 resulted in a natural gas discovery. By the end of the year, we should therefore have a much clearer picture of the future development options in Australia.In Libya, we have completed operations on two wells on our 100%-owned Area 54 license. In 2010, we will reprocess 3D seismic and begin discussions with the government about future plans and commercial options. In Brazil, we completed two wells, obtained 450 feet of core, and gathered a large amount of log and pressure data on the BM-S-22 license, in which Hess has a 40% interest. In 2010, the partnership will use this data to reprocess 3D seismic and drill a third well in the second half.In both Ghana and Sumai five [ph] in Indonesia, we continue to technically mature our 100% owned prospects during 2009, and expect to be in a position to drill in late 2010 or early 2011. Finally, in unconventional resources, we continue to selectively grow our position with the acquisition of 80,000 net acres in the Marcellus in 2009. In 2010, we will begin evaluation drilling and seek to acquire additional acreage. In closing, I'm very pleased with the performance of EP in 2009. We successfully navigated difficult business conditions in the early part of the year through tight spending controls and strong operating performance. We also continue to advance our portfolio of material exploration opportunities and strengthened our growth options for the future. Thank you. Now I'll hand the call over to John Rielly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare fourth quarter 2009 results to the third quarter. Fourth quarter 2009 consolidated results amounted to net income of $358 million, compared with $341 million in the third quarter.Turnin
componenttext: Thank you, Greg. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare fourth quarter 2009 results to the third quarter. Fourth quarter 2009 consolidated results amounted to net income of $358 million, compared with $341 million in the third quarter.Turning to Exploration and Production, Exploration and Production operations in the fourth quarter of 2009 had income of $494 million compared with $397 million in the third quarter. The third quarter included after-tax income of $89 million relating to the resolution of a royalty dispute on production from certain leases subject to the U.S. Deep Water Royalty Relief Act. Excluding the effect of the royalty matter, the after-tax components of the improved results are as follows: Higher selling prices increased earnings by $151 million, higher sales volumes increased earnings by $49 million all other items net to a decrease in earnings of $14 million, for an overall increase in fourth quarter adjusted earnings of $186 million.In the fourth quarter of 2009, our E&P operations were over-lifted compared with production, which increased after-tax income by approximately $40 million. However, earnings were lower in the fourth quarter by $20 million, due to deliveries of natural gas to partially settle take-or-pay operations at the JDA [Malaysia Thailand Joint Development Area] for volumes previously paid four by the buyers at the lower price. The E&P effective income tax rate was 47% for the fourth quarter of 2009. The E&P effective income tax rate was 48% the full year of 2009, excluding items affecting comparability between periods. Turning to Marketing and Refining, Marketing and Refining operations had income of $17 million in the fourth quarter of 2009, compared with income of $38 million in the third quarter, which included a non-recurring income tax benefit of $12 million. Refining operations lost $40 million in the fourth quarter compared with a loss of $15 million in the third quarter, excluding the non-recurring income tax benefit. The corporation share of HOVENSA's results after income taxes was a loss of $40 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $30 million in the third quarter, primarily reflecting lower margins. Port Reading broke even in the fourth quarter, compared with earnings of $16 million in the third quarter.Marketing earnings were $45 million in the fourth quarter of 2009, compared with $35 million in the third quarter, principally reflecting seasonally higher margins and refined product volumes in energy marketing operations. Trading activities generated income of $12 million in the fourth quarter, compared with income of $6 million in the third quarter.Turning to our bond offering and tender, in December 2009, the corporation issued $750 million of new 30-year bonds at a coupon of 6% and tendered for the $662 million of bonds due in August 2011. The corporation completed the repurchase of $546 million of 2011 bonds as of December 31. The remaining $116 million of bonds were redeemed in January and will result in an after-tax charge of approximately $7 million in the first quarter of 2010.Turning to Corporate, net Corporate expenses amounted to $97 million in the fourth quarter of 2009, compared with $33 million in the third quarter. Net corporate expenses in the fourth quarter included after-tax charges of $34 million for the repurchase of the $546 million of 2011 bonds referred to earlier, and $10 million for pension plan settlements related to employee retirements. Excluding the effect of these two items, net corporate expenses increased in the fourth quarter due to higher bank facility fees, employee-related expenses, insurance costs and lower returns from pension-related investments. For the full year 2009, net corporate expenses were $145 million, excluding items affecting comparability. After-tax interest expense was $56 million in the fourth quarter compared with $61 million in the third quarter. For the full year of 2009, after-tax interest expense was $224 million. Turning to cash flow, net cash provided by operating activities in the fourth quarter, including an increase of $256 million from changes in working capital, was $1,271,000,000. Net proceeds from the bond offering were $744 million. Repayments of debt amounted to $656 million. Capital expenditures were $925 million, all other items amounted to a decrease in cash flow of $29 million, resulting in a net increase in cash and cash equivalents in the fourth quarter of $405 million.We had $1,362,000,000 of cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2009, and $908 million at December 31, 2008. Our available revolving credit capacity was $3 billion at December 31, 2009. Total debt was $4,467,000,000 at December 31, 2009, and $3,955,000,000 at December 31, 2008. The corporation's debt-to-capitalization ratio at December 31, 2009, was 24.8% compared with 24.2% at the end of 2008. Now turning to 2010 guidance, in addition to the 2010 production and capital expenditure guidance given by John Hess, I would like to provide further information on certain 2010 financial metrics. Our E&P cash operating costs are expected to be in the range of $15 to $16 barrel oil equivalent produced. Depreciation, depletion and amortization charges are expected to be in the range of $14.50 to $15.50 per barrel for a total production unit cost of $29.50 to $31.50 per barrel of oil equivalent produced. For the full year of 2010, we currently expect our E&P effective tax rate to be in the range of 47% to 51%.In January 2010, HOVENSA commenced a turnaround of its FCC [fluid catalytic cracking] unit, which is expected to take approximately 40 days. The Corporation's estimated share after income taxes of HOVENSA's turnaround expenses is approximately $20 million. The Corporation is also planning a turnaround of approximately 35 days for the Port Reading refining facility in the second quarter 2010. The estimated after-tax expenses for the Port Reading turnaround are approximately $25 million.Net corporate expenses in 2010 are estimated to be in the range of $160 million to $170 million, and after-tax interest expense in 2010 is anticipated to be in the range of $220 million to $230 million. This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So what's going to drive the timing on both Ghana and Sumai Five [ph] in Indonesia is our technical readiness, so we're trying to get those wells ready to drill at the end of 2010. But that's going to depend upon whether we have all of our seismic reproce
componenttext: So what's going to drive the timing on both Ghana and Sumai Five [ph] in Indonesia is our technical readiness, so we're trying to get those wells ready to drill at the end of 2010. But that's going to depend upon whether we have all of our seismic reprocessing work done. In terms of the budget, what we've assumed is that we'll actually spud those wells in 2011. So obviously, if we pull those into the late fourth quarter, that will be some minor budget impact in 2010.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we've said is we will finish out our exploration drilling program by mid-year, July, August kind of time frame. What we're currently evaluating is additional appraisal wells on the back end of that program. I think obviously, as we get toward
componenttext: I think what we've said is we will finish out our exploration drilling program by mid-year, July, August kind of time frame. What we're currently evaluating is additional appraisal wells on the back end of that program. I think obviously, as we get towards at the end of the program and into our appraisal program, we'll have a much better understanding of what the total volume on the block is at that point in time.

componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I think this year, we are in discussions with Chevron, Shell, and what side about liquefaction options and anticipate being in those discussions for the majority of 2010.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, the buck and production target, 80,000 barrels a day, is kind of, is obviously a big number, it's kind of come out of nowhere if you compare it back to the last couple of years to where the focus was. Can you maybe just give just a little more color
componenttext: Greg, the buck and production target, 80,000 barrels a day, is kind of, is obviously a big number, it's kind of come out of nowhere if you compare it back to the last couple of years to where the focus was. Can you maybe just give just a little more color as to what exactly has gone on here in terms of why this has not been given such a high profile? And if I may just later on a related question, the operating costs from the likes of Brigham and Continental. Most of the guys out there are obviously much, much lower than your guidance of about, say, for the current year, so if this thing is going to be 20% of your production a couple of years down the line, why are we not seeing any drop in the guidance on cash flow operating cost. And I have a follow up for John Rielly, if that's okay.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: That'll be fine. So let me take the first question and then I'll turn it over to John after that. Really, what nothing's really changed in the Bakken. Of course, what happened in 2009, the oil price shock in the early part of the year, we were actually we
componenttext: That'll be fine. So let me take the first question and then I'll turn it over to John after that. Really, what nothing's really changed in the Bakken. Of course, what happened in 2009, the oil price shock in the early part of the year, we were actually well advanced in our thinking in the Bakken in late 2008 and we actually put the brakes on a bit in 2009, just to wait and see where the oil price was actually going to go. That actually gave us some breathing space to really get all of our plans together, figure out our contracting strategy, et cetera. And so really over the course of 2009, that's what we did. We finalized our thinking. We finalized our contracting strategy and then at the end of the year, took sanction on that project. So nothing's really changed and I'm thinking about the Bakken, it was just a timing thing related to the oil price shock in early 2009. Again, I'd like to remind everyone, the Bakken is robust at $40. It returns the cost to capital at $40. So that's why we feel very confident kind of pulling the trigger on the Bakken now, and aggressively going after a five-year program. I'll turn it over to John to answer the cost question.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the cost, and I guess you're referring to the overall cost figure that I gave for the portfolio. In the Bakken, and our cost are very competitive, we benchmark our drilling time and our cost there. So our cost are very competitive. But when you'
componenttext: As far as the cost, and I guess you're referring to the overall cost figure that I gave for the portfolio. In the Bakken, and our cost are very competitive, we benchmark our drilling time and our cost there. So our cost are very competitive. But when you're in the Bakken and we're in a growth mode, as Greg said as we're ramping up to 10 rigs, the amount of drilling activity there, it's fairly intensive at this point. And the overall cash costs in the Bakken are higher than our average of our portfolio. So at this point in time, actually the Bakken is one of the reasons that our overall cash costs in our portfolio are growing up. Now as Greg said, the returns are very good. We like the returns in the Bakken and obviously, we like being in the U.S. in the Shale play and the lower risk. But if you're looking at the one line from the cash cost standpoint, the Bakken does have an average production cost higher than our portfolio.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: Doug, I think you know we don't project that far into the future but of course, the reserve adds will be an annual reserve ad as we kind of drill out the acreage. So that gives you just some context.

Does that means that the play is not a priority and is the resource potential is really nothing exciting for you guys to talk about yet, or what's the reason why we haven't heard much about it?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean, the simple answer is, is we've got some well results, we're reprocessing seismic data and figuring out what our next steps are. So again, we prioritize all our investments in our global portfolio, and that's just where it's following in the seriat
componenttext: I mean, the simple answer is, is we've got some well results, we're reprocessing seismic data and figuring out what our next steps are. So again, we prioritize all our investments in our global portfolio, and that's just where it's following in the seriatim of ranking.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So we should just read that as of this point at least, based on what you've known when you rang it, this is a way behind Bakken, maybe high but still Ghana in everything, right?
componenttext: So we should just read that as of this point at least, based on what you've known when you rang it, this is a way behind Bakken, maybe high but still Ghana in everything, right?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair to say. It's in the queue later than those development programs.
componenttext: I think that's fair to say. It's in the queue later than those development programs.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And Greg, is there any -- you have not talked about, or maybe I missed it, if I do, I apologize. Have you talked about what is your deepwater Gulf of Mexico drilling program for this year, is there any interesting or high potential well that you're going
componenttext: And Greg, is there any -- you have not talked about, or maybe I missed it, if I do, I apologize. Have you talked about what is your deepwater Gulf of Mexico drilling program for this year, is there any interesting or high potential well that you're going to drill for the first six months of the year that we should be aware?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: In the Gulf of Mexico, our first well that we're going to drill on the Gulf will actually be the Pony appraisal well. And we'll drill that with a standard force in the early part of the year. After that, we're still trying to finalize the sequence, the Gu
componenttext: In the Gulf of Mexico, our first well that we're going to drill on the Gulf will actually be the Pony appraisal well. And we'll drill that with a standard force in the early part of the year. After that, we're still trying to finalize the sequence, the Gulf of Mexico relative to other parts of the world. Part of it depends on Ghana, Libya, some of these other things is to whether how we're going to utilize that rig and where she goes. But we just don't have a definitive answer on the Gulf of Mexico program beyond Pony at this point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Why would you be drilling another well in Pony, I thought that, that is already quite throughly drilled [ph] by say, early last year?
componenttext: Why would you be drilling another well in Pony, I thought that, that is already quite throughly drilled [ph] by say, early last year?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It is, but we have a block next door called 469, and so we'd like to drill a well in 469, and assuming it's successful, we'll bring that into the unit, what that also does is it allows us to hold the Block 469. So that's why we've decided that Pony apprai
componenttext: It is, but we have a block next door called 469, and so we'd like to drill a well in 469, and assuming it's successful, we'll bring that into the unit, what that also does is it allows us to hold the Block 469. So that's why we've decided that Pony appraisal well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So you're not actually drilling on the existing block for the Pony, you are actually drilling into a joined block and trying to see whether that's the rest of the expansion on that?
componenttext: So you're not actually drilling on the existing block for the Pony, you are actually drilling into a joined block and trying to see whether that's the rest of the expansion on that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: How far is that from the discovery or from the appraisal well?
componenttext: How far is that from the discovery or from the appraisal well?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Don't know the distance, but you can say it's probably about the half of Gulf of Mexico block to the edge of 469.
componenttext: Don't know the distance, but you can say it's probably about the half of Gulf of Mexico block to the edge of 469.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And when I looking at your capital spending, you're only going to spend $800 million for the development effort and far lower, I think that, then the percentage to the past that what you spend in the development. So other than Bakken, is there any other m
componenttext: And when I looking at your capital spending, you're only going to spend $800 million for the development effort and far lower, I think that, then the percentage to the past that what you spend in the development. So other than Bakken, is there any other major development project maybe coming on stream over the next two years?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. The way I'd rather think about this, Paul, is I don't really split it between production and development, so that's a bit of an arbitrary split and it's inside our own company. The big areas where we're spending money in 2010. Of course, North Dakota
componenttext: Yes. The way I'd rather think about this, Paul, is I don't really split it between production and development, so that's a bit of an arbitrary split and it's inside our own company. The big areas where we're spending money in 2010. Of course, North Dakota is the flagship. So that will be around $1 billion. Valhall, of course is in the final phase of its redevelopment. That will be around $650 million or so in Valhall, followed by the deepwater Gulf of Mexico. Next, about $300 million, that's a combination of Shenzi and some other wells that we're going to do in the Gulf. And then after that, it's a whole seriatim in $150 million to $100 million chunks really across the board.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, can you remind me, sorry that to recheck on so long, for the Valhall, when that the redevelopment is going to come on stream and what is the net production, do you guys going to be after the asset swap?
componenttext: Greg, can you remind me, sorry that to recheck on so long, for the Valhall, when that the redevelopment is going to come on stream and what is the net production, do you guys going to be after the asset swap?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well the bulk of the redevelopment work will be done by mid-2011. And so all of that work will be done by then and then you'll see additional wells be drilled and come on production.
componenttext: Well the bulk of the redevelopment work will be done by mid-2011. And so all of that work will be done by then and then you'll see additional wells be drilled and come on production.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And what is its net impact to you guys after the asset swap?
componenttext: And what is its net impact to you guys after the asset swap?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Just for information, Paul, in 2009, the net production for Valhall to us was 14,000 barrels a day. So that was again at our 28% interest so subsequent to this transaction, will double the 28% interest.
componenttext: Just for information, Paul, in 2009, the net production for Valhall to us was 14,000 barrels a day. So that was again at our 28% interest so subsequent to this transaction, will double the 28% interest.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: But I'm saying that after the completion of the redevelopment, what's the benefit that is going to be to you?
componenttext: But I'm saying that after the completion of the redevelopment, what's the benefit that is going to be to you?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think what Greg was saying, it will start once we start to doing the drilling. So the redevelopment again is replacing the facilities that are out there on the field, which will allow us to continue the development drilling and then the production will
componenttext: I think what Greg was saying, it will start once we start to doing the drilling. So the redevelopment again is replacing the facilities that are out there on the field, which will allow us to continue the development drilling and then the production will ramp up from there once the drilling starts and we'll have...

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So in other words, when you say complete by mid-2011, you're not going to see any increase in production as in perhaps after that as you ramp [ph] up on your tuning?
componenttext: So in other words, when you say complete by mid-2011, you're not going to see any increase in production as in perhaps after that as you ramp [ph] up on your tuning?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Kessler from Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Kessler from Simmons & Company.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: In the Bakken, it sounds like you added about 30 million barrels if I heard correctly. And I want to say the prior number on Bakken reserves was about 50. So can you confirm you're at about $80 million for the Bakken now? And then on Shenzi, given the pos
componenttext: In the Bakken, it sounds like you added about 30 million barrels if I heard correctly. And I want to say the prior number on Bakken reserves was about 50. So can you confirm you're at about $80 million for the Bakken now? And then on Shenzi, given the positive production performance there in 2009, any positive revisions to reserves?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: No, so let me just kind of highlight some of the major areas of reserve adds. As I said, the Bakken was about 31. We had some performance additions at Libya for another 24 to 25 million barrels. Russia and Okume were each just shy of 20 million barrels. I
componenttext: No, so let me just kind of highlight some of the major areas of reserve adds. As I said, the Bakken was about 31. We had some performance additions at Libya for another 24 to 25 million barrels. Russia and Okume were each just shy of 20 million barrels. It was really just across the board additions and revisions. And so the biggest single area, again, was the Bakken.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick one on the Bakken as well, you guys put out for data [ph] things from long-term service contracts, how close are you to those at this point? Have any been awarded or what's the expected timing from here?
componenttext: And then just a quick one on the Bakken as well, you guys put out for data [ph] things from long-term service contracts, how close are you to those at this point? Have any been awarded or what's the expected timing from here?

componenttext: Very close and imminent.

componenttext: And I'm assuming you're still fairly happy with what you've seen come back from contractors?

componenttextpreview: Yes, we are.
componenttext: Yes, we are.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bruce Lanni from NCPI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bruce Lanni from NCPI.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give a approximate breakout of the additions and revisions? That would be the first question. And so in other words, what's the net organic number out of that total?
componenttext: Can you give a approximate breakout of the additions and revisions? That would be the first question. And so in other words, what's the net organic number out of that total?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me see if I can walk you through this a bit. If you add back the price, the total addition from all forces is 192 million barrels. The only acquisition number in there is 16 million barrels. So if you take that out, the organic additions, your true or
componenttext: Let me see if I can walk you through this a bit. If you add back the price, the total addition from all forces is 192 million barrels. The only acquisition number in there is 16 million barrels. So if you take that out, the organic additions, your true organic additions are about 176 million barrels.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: But was the bulk of that through additions, revisions or actual drill bit, can you comment on that?
componenttext: But was the bulk of that through additions, revisions or actual drill bit, can you comment on that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So the bulk by far was through revisions. Of the 157 million in total, 144 million was associated with revisions, and 31 was associated with the extensions and discoveries and then 17 was associated with acquisitions so that gives you kind of the breakout
componenttext: So the bulk by far was through revisions. Of the 157 million in total, 144 million was associated with revisions, and 31 was associated with the extensions and discoveries and then 17 was associated with acquisitions so that gives you kind of the breakout of all three pieces.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: On Libya, can you add anymore color or detail to what you're seeing in Libya now that you have the two wells down? Do you have any idea of what the size you're dealing with and anything associated with that?
componenttext: On Libya, can you add anymore color or detail to what you're seeing in Libya now that you have the two wells down? Do you have any idea of what the size you're dealing with and anything associated with that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we don't yet. And I think what we can say is we've had two successful tests. The results of one was published, so that was about 27 million cubic feet and 500 barrels a day a condone [ph] site or so through a 50 to 60 force choke. The second well test
componenttext: No, we don't yet. And I think what we can say is we've had two successful tests. The results of one was published, so that was about 27 million cubic feet and 500 barrels a day a condone [ph] site or so through a 50 to 60 force choke. The second well test weren't published and that's because we don't have permission from the Libyan government. So we really can't speak too much about Libya. But suffice to say, we had two very successful tests.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Mark Gilman of Benchmark Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Mark Gilman of Benchmark Company.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: John Rielly, could you just clarify your comment about the impact of the take-or-pay situation on JDA? I guess I kind of lost you on that.
componenttext: John Rielly, could you just clarify your comment about the impact of the take-or-pay situation on JDA? I guess I kind of lost you on that.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: In prior years, actually it was in 2005, 2007 and 2008, the contract that we have with the JDA is take or pay. And so what happened is that the buyers pretty much with related to their pipeline, delivery to their pipeline, they couldn't take all the quant
componenttext: In prior years, actually it was in 2005, 2007 and 2008, the contract that we have with the JDA is take or pay. And so what happened is that the buyers pretty much with related to their pipeline, delivery to their pipeline, they couldn't take all the quantity of gas under the contract, so they paid us for that. And at that point in time, it was approximately 36 Bcf was in this gas bank. So now in the fourth quarter of 2009, they took 17.6 Bcf related to that gas bank. And so they had already paid for that gas at prices that were in effect in '05, '07 and '08. So what we had to do is essentially deliver that gas to them at basically those prices that we had built up deferred revenue associated with it. So they received that gas free when they start taking down the gas bank. And what we have is basically 18 Bcf left in the gas bank, and we have deferred revenue on our books of just under $80 million associated with that take-or-pay liability.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: John, when you refer to the 20 million hit, that was an opportunity cost?
componenttext: John, when you refer to the 20 million hit, that was an opportunity cost?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, compared to current market prices for the gas.
componenttext: Absolutely, compared to current market prices for the gas.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, I guess I'm a little unclear on what the economic and NPV merits are of the asset swap with Shell. I mean, no matter how I look at it, unless there's some big upside numbers, associated with the incremental resource on Valhall and incremental produc
componenttext: Greg, I guess I'm a little unclear on what the economic and NPV merits are of the asset swap with Shell. I mean, no matter how I look at it, unless there's some big upside numbers, associated with the incremental resource on Valhall and incremental production, it looks NPV negative, particularly with the front end increase in spend, as well as the very low profitability of those barrels, given the tax situation. Can you help me understand that a little bit?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. I think we see a significant upside in Valhall. This is a giant field with very, very low recovery factors so I think there's an awful lot more upside potential in Valhall. And we'll be working with the operator BP to unlock that upside potenti
componenttext: Yes, Mark. I think we see a significant upside in Valhall. This is a giant field with very, very low recovery factors so I think there's an awful lot more upside potential in Valhall. And we'll be working with the operator BP to unlock that upside potential. So we don't see it as value neutral at all. We see additional value.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: What's the recovery factor currently, Greg, and what do you think it can go to?
componenttext: What's the recovery factor currently, Greg, and what do you think it can go to?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to give you that number, but we can certainly call you back and give it to you. I don't know what it is off the top of my head.
componenttext: I'm not going to give you that number, but we can certainly call you back and give it to you. I don't know what it is off the top of my head.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us your current thoughts on length of plateau on production at both Shenzi and Siba, Okume going forward? How long do you think the plateau holds?
componenttext: Can you give us your current thoughts on length of plateau on production at both Shenzi and Siba, Okume going forward? How long do you think the plateau holds?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I wish I could. On Shenzi, I think we've been pleasantly surprised, pleased I guess with the performance of the aquifer. So how long that plateau lasts depends upon the performance of the aquifer and so far so good. Now of course, on Shenzi you have addit
componenttext: I wish I could. On Shenzi, I think we've been pleasantly surprised, pleased I guess with the performance of the aquifer. So how long that plateau lasts depends upon the performance of the aquifer and so far so good. Now of course, on Shenzi you have additional drilling opportunities as well that will keep that plateau for a number of years. But again, the big uncertainty is the aquifer and the pressure and how long does that hold.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Have you seen any pressure fall off in any of the wells yet?
componenttext: Have you seen any pressure fall off in any of the wells yet?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Not significant, so we're seeing good pressure support from the aquifer. Having said that, we're in the stages of planning for water injection, so I think the operator and us believe we ought to be conservative there, and make sure that we have adequate i
componenttext: Not significant, so we're seeing good pressure support from the aquifer. Having said that, we're in the stages of planning for water injection, so I think the operator and us believe we ought to be conservative there, and make sure that we have adequate injection support. Equatorial Guinea, we continue to drill additional wells there. We've got a number of years left to this kind of plateau production in Equatorial Guinea.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: If we could and I appreciate a lot has changed here but in many respects, that's the reason for the question, If we roll all the way back to the 2006 analyst meeting, the last analyst meeting, you talked about I believe 3% to 5% volume growth and 5% to 8%
componenttext: If we could and I appreciate a lot has changed here but in many respects, that's the reason for the question, If we roll all the way back to the 2006 analyst meeting, the last analyst meeting, you talked about I believe 3% to 5% volume growth and 5% to 8% reserves growth. Obviously, there's been a huge change here in regards to particularly it's the Bakken. We've also got a situation where you've talked about '09 as being a very strong year, well above our target for production growth. Not so much                next year on the volume growth side, can you just give me some idea of how you're thinking about the parameters of reserves growth going forward, relative to the game change in the Bakken and the higher CapEx that you have this year, The 9.5 year reserves and the aspiration I believe it was to get that to above 10. And any other sort of new parameters that we can think about it at a corporate long-term level relative to that previous target?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll be happy to try to fill this for you, Paul. It's a fair question. When we had the analyst meeting, we were definitely in the investment mode to grow our reserves, with the ultimate objective of getting to a reserve production life of 10, which we rea
componenttext: I'll be happy to try to fill this for you, Paul. It's a fair question. When we had the analyst meeting, we were definitely in the investment mode to grow our reserves, with the ultimate objective of getting to a reserve production life of 10, which we reached last year, and we're close to in terms of where we were at the year end. Our targets going forward, as you're well aware, over the last year or so, have evolved to where on a sustainable basis, to optimize financial returns, to set a 3% growth target per year for reserves and a 3% production target as well on an annual basis. Now that's really to be looked at, because you know the E&P business being so capital intensive and lumpy in the timing of developments. It's over the longer term. Year in, year out, like last year we were over 7%, now to 3%, 2010 closer to flat on production. But our long-term targets, meaning a five-year rolling average, we still aspire to and certainly feel that we have captured the opportunities in our portfolio of Exploration and Developments and production investments to deliver 3% a year reserve growth and 3% a year production growth. So those are the targets going forward. You can't judge us on a one-year basis, you have to do it over the long term, because this is a long-term business. And we feel very good between our Bakken program our exploration projects that we have in queue, the Pony project going forward, that we're pretty much on trend to meet those objectives.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask you to follow-up on SG&A, you mentioned $20 a barrel for the year again allowing for the lumpiness, what do you think the outlook for that is? Can you bring that number down by towards the average that you talked about, over five years
componenttext: If I could just ask you to follow-up on SG&A, you mentioned $20 a barrel for the year again allowing for the lumpiness, what do you think the outlook for that is? Can you bring that number down by towards the average that you talked about, over five years of $16 a barrel?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: That's all obviously very difficult to forecast, again with the lumpiness that we have. So Greg had mentioned we have the Pony sanctioned, that'll be coming up in 2011. Bakken will be more of a consistent provider. But again, with the way exploration proj
componenttext: That's all obviously very difficult to forecast, again with the lumpiness that we have. So Greg had mentioned we have the Pony sanctioned, that'll be coming up in 2011. Bakken will be more of a consistent provider. But again, with the way exploration projects and things like that come on stream, it's very difficult to forecast and where is industry cost going to go, where commodity cost going to go, so it's difficult. I mean, we're very focused on being as efficient as possible to drive that cost down as low as we can.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the Bakken obviously is bringing the costs down over time and I guess you're also seeing that it's going to be able to continue the sort of reserves outperformance that you've seen in '09?
componenttext: I guess the Bakken obviously is bringing the costs down over time and I guess you're also seeing that it's going to be able to continue the sort of reserves outperformance that you've seen in '09?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a fair assumption. So the Bakken will bring it down, and I think you'll see very similar kind of reserves add year-on-year. Obviously, the pace is going to up, so with that will come more reserve adds.
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a fair assumption. So the Bakken will bring it down, and I think you'll see very similar kind of reserves add year-on-year. Obviously, the pace is going to up, so with that will come more reserve adds.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: The swap with Shell, was there a net reserves impact from that?
componenttext: The swap with Shell, was there a net reserves impact from that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there will be. There will be a positive, upward revision to our account of over 100 million barrels this year.
componenttext: Yes, there will be. There will be a positive, upward revision to our account of over 100 million barrels this year.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: In turn, obviously?
componenttext: In turn, obviously?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: When I look at your year-end '09 versus year-end '08 reserves, could you tell me what the change would be had oil prices been constant year-over-year? In other words, how much did you lose through higher pricing under your production sharing contract?
componenttext: When I look at your year-end '09 versus year-end '08 reserves, could you tell me what the change would be had oil prices been constant year-over-year? In other words, how much did you lose through higher pricing under your production sharing contract?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So the price revisions and our reserves number were a negative 35 million barrels this year.
componenttext: So the price revisions and our reserves number were a negative 35 million barrels this year.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And is that essentially all under your BFCs overseas?
componenttext: And is that essentially all under your BFCs overseas?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I know you're testing kind of dual lateral, single lateral, trying to find the optimal well, I'm just curious if you have any estimate on kind of a time frame before you identify that. Presumably once you identify it and move to more of a program kind of
componenttext: I know you're testing kind of dual lateral, single lateral, trying to find the optimal well, I'm just curious if you have any estimate on kind of a time frame before you identify that. Presumably once you identify it and move to more of a program kind of drilling program, I'm assuming that should get you some efficiencies and help lower the costs but I wanted to kind of get your thinking on that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our development plan is to drill dual laterals, one in the three forks, one in the middle Bakken. And as I said earlier, We only have four wells done so far with that configuration. But suffice to say, they've been very successful. And the costs of a dual
componenttext: Our development plan is to drill dual laterals, one in the three forks, one in the middle Bakken. And as I said earlier, We only have four wells done so far with that configuration. But suffice to say, they've been very successful. And the costs of a dual lateral versus two single wells, there's quite a cost advantage there, and we're early on the learning curve, and we're also contracting rigs at a little bit better price. So I think you'll see those costs continue to drop. And we also plan to apply lean manufacturing to the play as well. So my experience with that is you'll see these costs continue to drop on the wells as we go forward.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: On the Marcellus, it looked like the verbiage in the release suggested you were looking to add acreage, I'm just curious if there's any kind of targeted amount and what your thinking is on entertaining new plays or just kind of focus of the Marcellus for the time being?

componenttextpreview: Yes I think we will be opportunistic in the Marcellus is what I'd say. There's still more acreage in and around our existing acreage that we would like to pick up. And in regards to your second part of your question, I think I've spoken about this before.
componenttext: Yes I think we will be opportunistic in the Marcellus is what I'd say. There's still more acreage in and around our existing acreage that we would like to pick up. And in regards to your second part of your question, I think I've spoken about this before. I mean, we view the globe as really the unconventional playground for us. So we are looking at a number of places around the globe at unconventional.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: Well, we have a plan in place for the infrastructure. Obviously, that's an issue for all the players in the Bakken. We're fortunate because we have a privileged infrastructure position already. So that will carry us through a period of time. And then after that, we're looking at rail options and/or pipeline options, and so I think you'll probably see both of those come into our future export strategies.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Francine, and I am your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to the host for
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Francine, and I am your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to the host for today, Mr. Jay Wilson, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Francine, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our fourth quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projection
componenttext: Thank you, Francine, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our fourth quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements. With me today are John Hess, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; Greg Hill, President, Worldwide Exploration and Production; and John Rielly, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. I will now turn the call over to John Hess.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Welcome to our Fourth Quarter Conference Call. I would like to review key achievements of 2009 and provide some guidance for 2010. Greg Hill will then discuss our Exploration and Production business, and John Rielly will review our financi
componenttext: Thank you, Jay. Welcome to our Fourth Quarter Conference Call. I would like to review key achievements of 2009 and provide some guidance for 2010. Greg Hill will then discuss our Exploration and Production business, and John Rielly will review our financial results. Corporate net income for the full year 2009 was $740 million. Exploration and Production earned $1.04 billion, and Marketing and Refining earned $127 million. While our earnings were down versus the previous year, our results reflected strong financial performance, increasing crude low prices throughout 2009 and successful cost reduction efforts.In terms of our 2010 capital and exploratory program, we are revising our budget to $4.1 billion from $3.9 billion. This increase of $200 million is the result of the strategic asset trade with Shell announced in December, in which we will assume Shell's interest in the Valhall and Hod fields in Norway in exchange for Hess' interest in the Clair field in the United Kingdom and all of Hess's interest in Gabon. The transaction is anticipated to close in the first quarter and be effective January 1, 2010.As another step to improve our portfolio, we completed the sale earlier this month of our interest in Jambi Merang in Indonesia receiving proceeds of $180 million. As in previous years, substantially all of our 2010 spending will be targeted to exploration and production with $2.4 billion budgeted for production operations, $800 million for developments and $850 million for exploration.With regard to exploration and production, in 2009, we replaced 103% of production at an FD&A costs of about $20 per barrel of oil equivalent. At year-end, our improved reserves stood at $1.44 billion barrels of oil equivalent and our reserve life was 9.5 years.In 2009, we increased crude oil and natural gas production 7% to 408,000 barrel equivalent of oil equivalent per day. In 2010, we forecast that crude oil and natural gas production will average between 400,000 and 410,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This forecast includes a net reduction of about 3,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day resulting from the strategic asset trade with Shell. With regard to developments, the Shenzi Field in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico in which Hess has a 30% interest, commence production in March and achieved a net rate of about $40,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day during the second half of 2009.We also sanctioned our Bakken Shale development in North Dakota. We plan to build up to a 10-rate program our next 18 months and invest about $1 billion per year over the next five years. As a result, we expect net production to increase from 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day currently to 80,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2015. In exploration we have continued success at 100%-owned, WA-390-P block at offshore Australia, where in 2009 we drilled seven was, six of which were natural gas discoveries. In Libya, we successfully flow tested the A1 discovery well on our 100% owned Area 54 license, and subsequently drilled and successfully flow tested it down to appraisal well.With regard to Marketing and Refining, our full-year 2009 financial results were lower than 2008, as the weak economy continue to have a negative impact on our business. Our HOVENSA joint venture refinery experienced losses as a result of significantly lower distillate crack spreads and narrower light-heavy crude low differentials.In retail marketing, our financial results were adversely affected by lower gasoline volumes, which were 3% in the last year and weaker margins, partially offset by higher convenience sources which were up nearly 11% from last year. In Energy Marketing, we generated stronger financial results, and increased sales of fuel oil and electricity.In 2009, we maintained a strong financial position in the face of a difficult economic environment. Our debt-to-capitalization ratio at the year-end was 24.8%, a slight increase over 2008. Our liquidity was enhanced by the February 2009 issuance of $1 billion of 10-year notes and $250 million of five-year notes to reduce short-term debt. Also in the fourth quarter of 2009, we refinanced notes due in 2011 by issuing $750 million of 30-year bonds.We are pleased with our performance during 2009, despite a challenging and volatile year. We remain committed to our strategy of investing to profitably grow our reserves and production on a sustainable basis. We are extremely excited about our future investment opportunities which we believe will create long-term value for our shareholders. I will now turn the call over to Greg Hill.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Let me begin with production. In 2009, crude oil and natural gas production averaged 408,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was up 7% versus 2008. Production growth was underpinned by strong performance from the Shenzi Field in
componenttext: Thank you, John. Let me begin with production. In 2009, crude oil and natural gas production averaged 408,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was up 7% versus 2008. Production growth was underpinned by strong performance from the Shenzi Field in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, a full-year Phase II natural gas sales for the Malaysia-Thailand joint development area, and overall solid operating performance. In 2009, we had improved reserves of 157 million barrels of oil equivalent and an FD&A cost of about $20 per barrel of oil equivalent, yielding a replacement ratio of 103% and an R/P ratio of 9.5, a good result considering the capital spending reductions we made and our strong production growth in 2009. Including this year's results, our five-year average reserve replacement ratio is 162%, and our average FD&A cost is about $16 per barrel of oil equivalent. In December, we announced a strategic asset trade with Shell that provides us with an opportunity to consolidate our portfolio and double our interest in the Valhall and Hod fields in Norway, which are long-lived producing assets with significant reserves and upside potential, which will further support our long-term objective of profitably growing our reserves and production.Turning to our capital program for 2010, we plan to invest nearly $1 billion in the Bakken Oil Plant in North Dakota, where we hold more than 500,000 net acres. We expect our average rig count to increase from three in 2009 to 10 in 2011. At Pony in the deep water Gulf of Mexico, we plan to drill an additional appraisal well, and anticipate unitization of Pony and Knotty Head in 2010, followed by a project sanction in 2011. The remainder of our capital program will focus on continued investment in a number of our core assets, including Shenzi, fields redevelopment at Valhall, an additional development drilling in Equatorial Guinea, the Malaysia-Thailand JDA and Pengka in Indonesia. Turning to exploration, in Australia, as a result of the 2009 drilling program on a 100% owned Western Australia 390-P license, we have now drilled 11 of the 16 commitment wells on the block and have had nine discoveries. We plan to drill additional five commitment wells during the first half of 2010, and are considering further appraisal wells. At the same time, we are continuing discussions regarding commercialization. Also at the Western Australia 404-P license, in  which half of the 50% interest the operator would side, we'll drill eight wells during 2010. Earlier this week, the operator announced that the first of these wells, Noblige-1 resulted in a natural gas discovery. By the end of the year, we should therefore have a much clearer picture of the future development options in Australia.In Libya, we have completed operations on two wells on our 100%-owned Area 54 license. In 2010, we will reprocess 3D seismic and begin discussions with the government about future plans and commercial options.In Brazil, we completed two wells, obtained 450 feet of core, and gathered a large amount of log and pressure data on the BM-S-22 license, in which Hess has a 40% interest. In 2010, the partnership will use this data to reprocess 3D seismic and drill a third well in the second half.In both Ghana and Sumai five [ph] in Indonesia, we continue to technically mature our 100% owned prospects during 2009, and expect to be in a position to drill in late 2010 or early 2011. Finally, in unconventional resources, we continue to selectively grow our position with the acquisition of 80,000 net acres in the Marcellus in 2009. In 2010, we will begin evaluation drilling and seek to acquire additional acreage. In closing, I'm very pleased with the performance of EP in 2009. We successfully navigated difficult business conditions in the early part of the year through tight spending controls and strong operating performance. We also continue to advance our portfolio of material exploration opportunities and strengthened our growth options for the future. Thank you. Now I'll hand the call over to John Rielly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare fourth quarter 2009 results to the third quarter. Fourth quarter 2009 consolidated results amounted to net income of $358 million, compared with $341 million in the third quarter.Turnin
componenttext: Thank you, Greg. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare fourth quarter 2009 results to the third quarter. Fourth quarter 2009 consolidated results amounted to net income of $358 million, compared with $341 million in the third quarter.Turning to Exploration and Production, Exploration and Production operations in the fourth quarter of 2009 had income of $494 million compared with $397 million in the third quarter. The third quarter included after-tax income of $89 million relating to the resolution of a royalty dispute on production from certain leases subject to the U.S. Deep Water Royalty Relief Act. Excluding the effect of the royalty matter, the after-tax components of the improved results are as follows: Higher selling prices increased earnings by $151 million, higher sales volumes increased earnings by $49 million all other items net to a decrease in earnings of $14 million, for an overall increase in fourth quarter adjusted earnings of $186 million.In the fourth quarter of 2009, our E&P operations were over-lifted compared with production, which increased after-tax income by approximately $40 million. However, earnings were lower in the fourth quarter by $20 million, due to deliveries of natural gas to partially settle take-or-pay operations at the JDA [Malaysia Thailand Joint Development Area] for volumes previously paid four by the buyers at the lower price. The E&P effective income tax rate was 47% for the fourth quarter of 2009. The E&P effective income tax rate was 48% the full year of 2009, excluding items affecting comparability between periods. Turning to Marketing and Refining, Marketing and Refining operations had income of $17 million in the fourth quarter of 2009, compared with income of $38 million in the third quarter, which included a non-recurring income tax benefit of $12 million. Refining operations lost $40 million in the fourth quarter compared with a loss of $15 million in the third quarter, excluding the non-recurring income tax benefit. The corporation share of HOVENSA's results after income taxes was a loss of $40 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $30 million in the third quarter, primarily reflecting lower margins. Port Reading broke even in the fourth quarter, compared with earnings of $16 million in the third quarter.Marketing earnings were $45 million in the fourth quarter of 2009, compared with $35 million in the third quarter, principally reflecting seasonally higher margins and refined product volumes in energy marketing operations. Trading activities generated income of $12 million in the fourth quarter, compared with income of $6 million in the third quarter.Turning to our bond offering and tender, in December 2009, the corporation issued $750 million of new 30-year bonds at a coupon of 6% and tendered for the $662 million of bonds due in August 2011. The corporation completed the repurchase of $546 million of 2011 bonds as of December 31. The remaining $116 million of bonds were redeemed in January and will result in an after-tax charge of approximately $7 million in the first quarter of 2010.Turning to Corporate, net Corporate expenses amounted to $97 million in the fourth quarter of 2009, compared with $33 million in the third quarter. Net corporate expenses in the fourth quarter included after-tax charges of $34 million for the repurchase of the $546 million of 2011 bonds referred to earlier, and $10 million for pension plan settlements related to employee retirements. Excluding the effect of these two items, net corporate expenses increased in the fourth quarter due to higher bank facility fees, employee-related expenses, insurance costs and lower returns from pension-related investments. For the full year 2009, net corporate expenses were $145 million, excluding items affecting comparability. After-tax interest expense was $56 million in the fourth quarter compared with $61 million in the third quarter. For the full year of 2009, after-tax interest expense was $224 million. Turning to cash flow, net cash provided by operating activities in the fourth quarter, including an increase of $256 million from changes in working capital, was $1,271,000,000. Net proceeds from the bond offering were $744 million. Repayments of debt amounted to $656 million. Capital expenditures were $925 million, all other items amounted to a decrease in cash flow of $29 million, resulting in a net increase in cash and cash equivalents in the fourth quarter of $405 million.We had $1,362,000,000 of cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2009, and $908 million at December 31, 2008. Our available revolving credit capacity was $3 billion at December 31, 2009. Total debt was $4,467,000,000 at December 31, 2009, and $3,955,000,000 at December 31, 2008. The corporation's debt-to-capitalization ratio at December 31, 2009, was 24.8% compared with 24.2% at the end of 2008. Now turning to 2010 guidance, in addition to the 2010 production and capital expenditure guidance given by John Hess, I would like to provide further information on certain 2010 financial metrics. Our E&P cash operating costs are expected to be in the range of $15 to $16 barrel oil equivalent produced. Depreciation, depletion and amortization charges are expected to be in the range of $14.50 to $15.50 per barrel for a total production unit cost of $29.50 to $31.50 per barrel of oil equivalent produced. For the full year of 2010, we currently expect our E&P effective tax rate to be in the range of 47% to 51%.In January 2010, HOVENSA commenced a turnaround of its FCC [fluid catalytic cracking] unit, which is expected to take approximately 40 days. The Corporation's estimated share after income taxes of HOVENSA's turnaround expenses is approximately $20 million. The Corporation is also planning a turnaround of approximately 35 days for the Port Reading refining facility in the second quarter 2010. The estimated after-tax expenses for the Port Reading turnaround are approximately $25 million.Net corporate expenses in 2010 are estimated to be in the range of $160 million to $170 million, and after-tax interest expense in 2010 is anticipated to be in the range of $220 million to $230 million. This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So what's going to drive the timing on both Ghana and Sumai Five [ph] in Indonesia is our technical readiness, so we're trying to get those wells ready to drill at the end of 2010. But that's going to depend upon whether we have all of our seismic reproce
componenttext: So what's going to drive the timing on both Ghana and Sumai Five [ph] in Indonesia is our technical readiness, so we're trying to get those wells ready to drill at the end of 2010. But that's going to depend upon whether we have all of our seismic reprocessing work done. In terms of the budget, what we've assumed is that we'll actually spud those wells in 2011. So obviously, if we pull those into the late fourth quarter, that will be some minor budget impact in 2010.

componenttext: I think what we've said is we will finish out our exploration drilling program by mid-year, July, August kind of time frame. What we're currently evaluating is additional appraisal wells on the back end of that program. I think obviously, as we get towards at the end of the program and into our appraisal program, we'll have a much better understanding of what the total volume on the block is at that point in time.

componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I think this year, we are in discussions with Chevron, Shell, and what side about liquefaction options and anticipate being in those discussions for the majority of 2010.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
