componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate from Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, the buck and production target, 80,000 barrels a day, is kind of, is obviously a big number, it's kind of come out of nowhere if you compare it back to the last couple of years to where the focus was. Can you maybe just give just a little more color
componenttext: Greg, the buck and production target, 80,000 barrels a day, is kind of, is obviously a big number, it's kind of come out of nowhere if you compare it back to the last couple of years to where the focus was. Can you maybe just give just a little more color as to what exactly has gone on here in terms of why this has not been given such a high profile? And if I may just later on a related question, the operating costs from the likes of Brigham and Continental. Most of the guys out there are obviously much, much lower than your guidance of about, say, for the current year, so if this thing is going to be 20% of your production a couple of years down the line, why are we not seeing any drop in the guidance on cash flow operating cost. And I have a follow up for John Rielly, if that's okay.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: That'll be fine. So let me take the first question and then I'll turn it over to John after that. Really, what nothing's really changed in the Bakken. Of course, what happened in 2009, the oil price shock in the early part of the year, we were actually we
componenttext: That'll be fine. So let me take the first question and then I'll turn it over to John after that. Really, what nothing's really changed in the Bakken. Of course, what happened in 2009, the oil price shock in the early part of the year, we were actually well advanced in our thinking in the Bakken in late 2008 and we actually put the brakes on a bit in 2009, just to wait and see where the oil price was actually going to go. That actually gave us some breathing space to really get all of our plans together, figure out our contracting strategy, et cetera. And so really over the course of 2009, that's what we did. We finalized our thinking. We finalized our contracting strategy and then at the end of the year, took sanction on that project. So nothing's really changed and I'm thinking about the Bakken, it was just a timing thing related to the oil price shock in early 2009. Again, I'd like to remind everyone, the Bakken is robust at $40. It returns the cost to capital at $40. So that's why we feel very confident kind of pulling the trigger on the Bakken now, and aggressively going after a five-year program. I'll turn it over to John to answer the cost question.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the cost, and I guess you're referring to the overall cost figure that I gave for the portfolio. In the Bakken, and our cost are very competitive, we benchmark our drilling time and our cost there. So our cost are very competitive. But when you'
componenttext: As far as the cost, and I guess you're referring to the overall cost figure that I gave for the portfolio. In the Bakken, and our cost are very competitive, we benchmark our drilling time and our cost there. So our cost are very competitive. But when you're in the Bakken and we're in a growth mode, as Greg said as we're ramping up to 10 rigs, the amount of drilling activity there, it's fairly intensive at this point. And the overall cash costs in the Bakken are higher than our average of our portfolio. So at this point in time, actually the Bakken is one of the reasons that our overall cash costs in the portfolio are going up. Now as Greg said, the returns are very good. We like the returns in the Bakken and obviously we like being in the U.S. and the shale playing the lower risk but if you're looking at the one line from the cash cost standpoint, the Bakken does have an average production cost higher than our portfolio.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: The cash operating costs is only around $6, does that sound about right, in the Bakken?
componenttext: The cash operating costs is only around $6, does that sound about right, in the Bakken?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: You see we actually don't get into individual aspects of it. But again, as I say and Doug the cash cost in the Bakken are above the average of our portfolio.

componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess I'm thinking more about a run rate versus your competitors as you move forward. The follow-up I had that maybe isn't for John Rielly, but I'll see which one of you guys wants to take this, but reserve replacement, if you've got a five-year p
componenttext: Sure. I guess I'm thinking more about a run rate versus your competitors as you move forward. The follow-up I had that maybe isn't for John Rielly, but I'll see which one of you guys wants to take this, but reserve replacement, if you've got a five-year program, $1 billion a year, again related to the Bakken, what are we talking about in terms of reserved adds and how are we like to see that given the project has been sanctioned, how are we like to see those as we move forward?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: Doug, I think you know we don't project that far into the future but of course, the reserve adds will be an annual reserve ad as we kind of drill out the acreage. And Just to give you some perspective, I mean, in our reserve adds of $157 million this year. The Bakken was about 30, 31 million barrels associated with the three-rig program. So that gives you just some context.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: Greg, just to clarify on this and you've talked about dual laterals. A million barrels per dual lateral, is that still a good number?

componenttext: Yes, I think at this point that's still a pretty good number. To be fair, we only have four dual laterals in the ground now, so I think it's a little early to give definitive numbers about that. But I think at this point in the play, that's probably a decent number.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And Greg, is there any -- you have not talked about, or maybe I missed it, if I do, I apologize. Have you talked about what is your deepwater Gulf of Mexico drilling program for this year, is there any interesting or high potential well that you're going
componenttext: And Greg, is there any -- you have not talked about, or maybe I missed it, if I do, I apologize. headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: In the Gulf of Mexico, our first well that we're going to drill on the Gulf will actually be the Pony appraisal well. And we'll drill that with a standard force in the early part of the year. After that, we're still trying to finalize the sequence, the Gu
componenttext: In the Gulf of Mexico, our first well that we're going to drill on the Gulf will actually be the Pony appraisal well. And we'll drill that with a standard force in the early part of the year. After that, we're still trying to finalize the sequence, the Gulf of Mexico relative to other parts of the world. Part of it depends on Ghana, Libya, some of these other things is to whether how we're going to utilize that rig and where she goes. But we just don't have a definitive answer on the Gulf of Mexico program beyond Pony at this point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Why would you be drilling another well in Pony, I thought that, that is already quite throughly drilled by say, early last year?
componenttext: Why would you be drilling another well in Pony, I thought that, that is already quite throughly drilled by say, early last year?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It is, but we have a block next door called 469, and so we'd like to drill a well in 469, and assuming it's successful, we'll bring that into the unit, what that also does is it allows us to hold the Block 469. So that's why we've decided that Pony apprai
componenttext: It is, but we have a block next door called 469, and so we'd like to drill a well in 469, and assuming it's successful, we'll bring that into the unit, what that also does is it allows us to hold the Block 469. So that's why we've decided that Pony appraisal well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So you're not actually drilling on the existing block for the Pony, you are actually drilling into a joined block and trying to see whether that's the rest of the expansion on that?
componenttext: So you're not actually drilling on the existing block for the Pony, you are actually drilling into a joined block and trying to see whether that's the rest of the expansion on that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: How far is that from the discovery or from the appraisal well?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: And when I looking at your capital spending you're only going to spend $800 million for the development effort and far lower. I think that, then the percentage to the past that what you spend in the development. So other than Bakken, is there any other major development project maybe coming on stream over the next two years?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. The way I'd rather think about this, Paul, is I don't really split it between production and development, so that's a bit of an arbitrary split and it's inside our own company. The big areas where we're spending money in 2010. Of course, North Dakota
componenttext: Yes. The way I'd rather think about this, Paul, is I don't really split it between production and development, so that's a bit of an arbitrary split and it's inside our own company. The big areas where we're spending money in 2010. Of course, North Dakota is the flagship. So that will be around $1 billion. Valhall, of course is in the final phase of its redevelopment. That will be around $650 million or so in Valhall, followed by the deepwater Gulf of Mexico. Next, about $300 million, that's a combination of Shenzi and some other wells that we're going to do in the Gulf. And then after that, it's a whole seriatim in $150 million to $100 million chunks really across-the-board.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: Well the bulk of the redevelopment work will be done by mid-2011. And so all of that work will be done by then and then you'll see additional wells be drilled and come on production.

componenttext: Just for information, Paul, in 2009, the net production for Valhall to us was 14,000 barrels a day. So that was again at our 28% interest so subsequent to this transaction, will double the 28% interest.

So the redevelopment again is replacing the facilities that are out there on the field, which will allow us to continue the development drilling and then the production will ramp up from there once the drilling starts and we'll have...

componenttext: In the Bakken, it sounds like you added about 30 million barrels if I heard correctly. And I want to say the prior number on Bakken reserves was about 50. So can you confirm you're at about $80 million for the Bakken now? And then on Shenzi, given the positive production performance there in 2009, any positive revisions to reserves?

componenttext: No, so let me just kind of highlight some of the major areas of reserve adds. As I said, the Bakken was about 31. We had some performance additions at Libya for another 24 to 25 million barrels. Russia and Okume were each just shy of 20 million barrels. It was really just across the board additions and revisions. And so the biggest single area, again, was the Bakken.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: Let me see if I can walk you through this a bit. If you add back the price, the total addition from all forces is 192 million barrels. The only acquisition number in there is 16 million barrels. So if you take that out, the organic additions, your true organic additions are about 176 million barrels.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: But was the bulk of that through additions, revisions or actual drill bit, can you comment on that?
componenttext: But was the bulk of that through additions, revisions or actual drill bit, can you comment on that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So the bulk by far was through revisions. Of the 157 million in total, 144 million was associated with revisions, and 31 was associated with the extensions and discoveries and then 17 was associated with acquisitions so that gives you kind of the breakout
componenttext: So the bulk by far was through revisions. Of the 157 million in total, 144 million was associated with revisions, and 31 was associated with the extensions and discoveries and then 17 was associated with acquisitions so that gives you kind of the breakout of all three pieces.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: On Libya, can you add anymore color or detail to what you're seeing in Libya now that you have the two wells down? Do you have any idea of what the size you're dealing with and anything associated with that?
componenttext: On Libya, can you add anymore color or detail to what you're seeing in Libya now that you have the two wells down? Do you have any idea of what the size you're dealing with and anything associated with that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we don't yet. And I think what we can say is we've had two successful tests. The results of one was published, so that was about 27 million cubic feet and 500 barrels a day a condone [ph] site or so through a 50 to 60 force choke. The second well test
componenttext: No, we don't yet. And I think what we can say is we've had two successful tests. The results of one was published, so that was about 27 million cubic feet and 500 barrels a day a condone [ph] site or so through a 50 to 60 force choke. The second well test weren't published and that's because we don't have permission from the Libyan government. So we really can't speak too much about Libya. But suffice to say, we had two very successful tests.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Mark Gilman of Benchmark Company.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: John Rielly, could you just clarify your comment about the impact of the take-or-pay situation on JDA? I guess I kind of lost you on that.
componenttext: John Rielly, could you just clarify your comment about the impact of the take-or-pay situation on JDA? I guess I kind of lost you on that.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: In prior years, actually it was in 2005, 2007 and 2008, the contract that we have with the JDA is take or pay. And so what happened is that the buyers pretty much with related to their pipeline, delivery to their pipeline, they couldn't take all the quant
componenttext: In prior years, actually it was in 2005, 2007 and 2008, the contract that we have with the JDA is take or pay. And so what happened is that the buyers pretty much with related to their pipeline, delivery to their pipeline, they couldn't take all the quantity of gas under the contract, so they paid us for that. And at that point in time, it was approximately 36 Bcf was in this gas bank. So now in the fourth quarter of 2009, they took 17.6 Bcf related to that gas bank. And so they had already paid for that gas at prices that were in effect in '05, '07 and '08. So what we had to do is essentially deliver that gas to them at basically those prices that we had built up deferred revenue associated with it. So they received that gas free when they start taking down the gas bank. And what we have is basically 18 Bcf left in the gas bank, and we have deferred revenue on our books of just under $80 million associated with that take-or-pay liability.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: John, when you refer to the 20 million hit, that was an opportunity cost?
componenttext: John, when you refer to the 20 million hit, that was an opportunity cost?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, compared to current market prices for the gas.
componenttext: Absolutely, compared to current market prices for the gas.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, I guess I'm a little unclear on what the economic and NPV merits are of the asset swap with Shell. I mean, no matter how I look at it, unless there's some big upside numbers, associated with the incremental resource on Valhall and incremental produc
componenttext: Greg, I guess I'm a little unclear on what the economic and NPV merits are of the asset swap with Shell. I mean, no matter how I look at it, unless there's some big upside numbers, associated with the incremental resource on Valhall and incremental production, it looks NPV negative, particularly with the front end increase in spend, as well as the very low profitability of those barrels, given the tax situation. Can you help me understand that a little bit?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. I think we see a significant upside in Valhall. This is a giant field with very, very low recovery factors so I think there's an awful lot more upside potential in Valhall. And we'll be working with the operator BP to unlock that upside potenti
componenttext: Yes, Mark. I think we see a significant upside in Valhall. This is a giant field with very, very low recovery factors so I think there's an awful lot more upside potential in Valhall. And we'll be working with the operator BP to unlock that upside potential. So we don't see it as value neutral at all. We see additional value.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: What's the recovery factor currently, Greg, and what do you think it can go to?
componenttext: What's the recovery factor currently, Greg, and what do you think it can go to?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to give you that number, but we can certainly call you back and give it to you. I don't know what it is off the top of my head.
componenttext: I'm not going to give you that number, but we can certainly call you back and give it to you. I don't know what it is off the top of my head.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us your current thoughts on length of plateau on production at both Shenzi and Siba, Okume going forward? How long do you think the plateau holds?
componenttext: Can you give us your current thoughts on length of plateau on production at both Shenzi and Siba, Okume going forward? How long do you think the plateau holds?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I wish I could. On Shenzi, I think we've been pleasantly surprised, pleased I guess with the performance of the aquifer. So how long that plateau lasts depends upon the performance of the aquifer and so far so good. Now of course, on Shenzi you have addit
componenttext: I wish I could. On Shenzi, I think we've been pleasantly surprised, pleased I guess with the performance of the aquifer. So how long that plateau lasts depends upon the performance of the aquifer and so far so good. Now of course, on Shenzi you have additional drilling opportunities as well that will keep that plateau for a number of years. But again, the big uncertainty is the aquifer and the pressure and how long does that hold.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Have you seen any pressure fall off in any of the wells yet?
componenttext: Have you seen any pressure fall off in any of the wells yet?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Not significant, so we're seeing good pressure support from the aquifer. Having said that, we're in the stages of planning for water injection, so I think the operator and us believe we ought to be conservative there, and make sure that we have adequate i
componenttext: Not significant, so we're seeing good pressure support from the aquifer. Having said that, we're in the stages of planning for water injection, so I think the operator and us believe we ought to be conservative there, and make sure that we have adequate injection support. Equatorial Guinea, we continue to drill additional wells there. We've got a number of years left to this kind of plateau production in Equatorial Guinea.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: If we could and I appreciate a lot has changed here but in many respects, that's the reason for the question, If we roll all the way back to the 2006 analyst meeting, the last analyst meeting, you talked about I believe 3% to 5% volume growth and 5% to 8%
componenttext: If we could and I appreciate a lot has changed here but in many respects, that's the reason for the question, If we roll all the way back to the 2006 analyst meeting, the last analyst meeting, you talked about I believe 3% to 5% volume growth and 5% to 8% reserves growth. Obviously, there's been a huge change here in regards to particularly it's the Bakken. We've also got a situation where you've talked about '09 as being a very strong year, well above our target for production growth. Not so much                next year on the volume growth side, can you just give me some idea of how you're thinking about the parameters of reserves growth going forward, relative to the game change in the Bakken and the higher CapEx that you have this year, The 9.5 year reserves and the aspiration I believe it was to get that to above 10. And any other sort of new parameters that we can think about it at a corporate long-term level relative to that previous target?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll be happy to try to fill this for you, Paul. It's a fair question. When we had the analyst meeting, we were definitely in the investment mode to grow our reserves, with the ultimate objective of getting to a reserve production life of 10, which we rea
componenttext: I'll be happy to try to fill this for you, Paul. It's a fair question. When we had the analyst meeting, we were definitely in the investment mode to grow our reserves, with the ultimate objective of getting to a reserve production life of 10, which we reached last year, and we're close to in terms of where we were at the year end. Our targets going forward, as you're well aware, over the last year or so, have evolved to where on a sustainable basis, to optimize financial returns, to set a 3% growth target per year for reserves and a 3% production target as well on an annual basis. Now that's really to be looked at, because you know the E&P business being so capital intensive and lumpy in the timing of developments. It's over the longer term. Year in, year out, like last year we were over 7%, now to 3%, 2010 closer to flat on production. But our long-term targets, meaning a five-year rolling average, we still aspire to and certainly feel that we have captured the opportunities in our portfolio of Exploration and Developments and production investments to deliver 3% a year reserve growth and 3% a year production growth. So those are the targets going forward. You can't judge us on a one-year basis, you have to do it over the long term, because this is a long-term business. And we feel very good between our Bakken program our exploration projects that we have in queue, the Pony project going forward, that we're pretty much on trend to meet those objectives.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask you to follow-up on SG&A, you mentioned $20 a barrel for the year again allowing for the lumpiness, what do you think the outlook for that is? Can you bring that number down by towards the average that you talked about, over five years
componenttext: If I could just ask you to follow-up on SG&A, you mentioned $20 a barrel for the year again allowing for the lumpiness, what do you think the outlook for that is? Can you bring that number down by towards the average that you talked about, over five years of $16 a barrel?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: That's all obviously very difficult to forecast, again with the lumpiness that we have. So Greg had mentioned we have the Pony sanctioned, that'll be coming up in 2011. Bakken will be more of a consistent provider. But again, with the way exploration proj
componenttext: That's all obviously very difficult to forecast, again with the lumpiness that we have. So Greg had mentioned we have the Pony sanctioned, that'll be coming up in 2011. Bakken will be more of a consistent provider. But again, with the way exploration projects and things like that come on stream, it's very difficult to forecast and where is industry cost going to go, where commodity cost going to go, so it's difficult. I mean, we're very focused on being as efficient as possible to drive that cost down as low as we can.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the Bakken obviously is bringing the costs down over time and I guess you're also seeing that it's going to be able to continue the sort of reserves outperformance that you've seen in '09?

componenttextpreview: I know you're testing kind of dual lateral, single lateral, trying to find the optimal well, I'm just curious if you have any estimate on kind of a time frame before you identify that. Presumably once you identify it and move to more of a program kind of
componenttext: I know you're testing kind of dual lateral, single lateral, trying to find the optimal well, I'm just curious if you have any estimate on kind of a time frame before you identify that. Presumably once you identify it and move to more of a program kind of drilling program, I'm assuming that should get you some efficiencies and help lower the costs but I wanted to kind of get your thinking on that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our development plan is to drill dual laterals, one in the three forks, one in the middle Bakken. And as I said earlier, We only have four wells done so far with that configuration. But suffice to say, they've been very successful. And the costs of a dual
componenttext: Our development plan is to drill dual laterals, one in the three forks, one in the middle Bakken. And as I said earlier, We only have four wells done so far with that configuration. But suffice to say, they've been very successful. And the costs of a dual lateral versus two single wells, there's quite a cost advantage there, and we're early on the learning curve, and we're also contracting rigs at a little bit better price. So I think you'll see those costs continue to drop. And we also plan to apply lean manufacturing to the play as well. So my experience with that is you'll see these costs continue to drop on the wells as we go forward.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010

componenttext: On the Marcellus, it looked like the verbiage in the release suggested you were looking to add acreage, I'm just curious if there's any kind of targeted amount and what your thinking is on entertaining new plays or just kind of focus of the Marcellus for the time being?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes I think we will be opportunistic in the Marcellus is what I'd say. There's still more acreage in and around our existing acreage that we would like to pick up. And in regards to your second part of your question, I think I've spoken about this before.
componenttext: Yes I think we will be opportunistic in the Marcellus is what I'd say. There's still more acreage in and around our existing acreage that we would like to pick up. And in regards to your second part of your question, I think I've spoken about this before. I mean, we view the globe as really the unconventional playground for us. So we are looking at a number of places around the globe at unconventional.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a plan in place for the infrastructure. Obviously, that's an issue for all the players in the Bakken. We're fortunate because we have a privileged infrastructure position already. So that will carry us through a period of time. And then afte
componenttext: Well, we have a plan in place for the infrastructure. Obviously, that's an issue for all the players in the Bakken. We're fortunate because we have a privileged infrastructure position already. So that will carry us through a period of time. And then after that, we're looking at rail options and/or pipeline options, and so I think you'll probably see both of those come into our future export strategies.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference call. My name is Madge and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Jay Wilson, Vice
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference call. My name is Madge and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Jay Wilson, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Madge, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears in our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections an
componenttext:
Thank you, Madge, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears in our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements.
With me today are John Hess, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; Greg Hill, President, Worldwide Exploration and Production; and John Reilly, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
I'll now turn the call over to John Hess.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and welcome to our first quarter conference call. I will make a few brief comments, after which John Reilly will review our financial results.Net income for the first quarter of 2010 was $538 million versus a loss of $59 million a year a
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and welcome to our first quarter conference call. I will make a few brief comments, after which John Reilly will review our financial results.
Net income for the first quarter of 2010 was $538 million versus a loss of $59 million a year ago. Our earnings were positively impacted by higher crude oil and natural gas selling prices and production volumes that more than offset the impact of weaker refining results.
Exploration and Production earned $551 million. Crude oil and natural gas production averaged 423,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was 8% above the year ago quarter. This increase resulted primarily from higher production from the Shenzi and Conger Fields in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico and the JDA in the Gulf of Thailand.
In January we closed the previously announced sale of our Jambi Merang asset in Indonesia, receiving proceeds of $183 million. 
At the end of March, we announced the sale of a package of mature, non-operated natural gas production and transportation assets in the U.K. North Sea for $423 million. The sale, which is expected to close in the third quarter, is part of the company's ongoing portfolio management efforts.
We also continue to make progress in finalizing our previously announced strategic asset trade with Shell, which is now expected to close in the second half of this year.  In this trade, Hess will assume Shell's 28.09% interest in the Valhall field and 25% interest in the satellite Hod field in Norway. In return, Shell will assume Hess' 9.29% interest in the Clair Field in the United Kingdom and all of Hess' interest in Gabon.
Although the net effect of these asset sales and the strategic asset trade with Shell is to reduce full year 2010 production by approximately 5,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, our 2010 production forecast remains at 400,000 to 410,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
In North Dakota, net production from the Bakken reached 13,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in March. We currently have five rigs dedicated to drilling Bakken wells and we plan to add five additional rigs over the next 12 months.
With regard to exploration, drilling is continuing on Permits WA-390-P and WA-404-P in the Northwest Shelf of Australia. Also, discussions with potential partners regarding the commercialization of natural gas resources on our 100% owned WA-390-P Block are ongoing. 
In February, we spud the Pony No. 3 well on Green Canyon 469, in which Hess has a 100% working interest. This well, which is still drilling, is designed to test the eastern extent of the Pony structure.  Due to a previous farmout agreement regarding the Stena Forth drillship, we plan to release the rig in early June to another operator and then bring it back to finish drilling the well in the fourth quarter. 
In Brazil, the operator of Block BM-S-22 is in the process of completing the analysis of seismic, log and core data and plans to drill a third well in the second half of 2010. Hess has a 40% working interest in the block. 
In Indonesia, we have secured a rig to drill the Semai V prospect, in which Hess has 100% working interest. This well is expected to spud by the first quarter of 2011. With regard to our Deepwater Tano Cape Three Points Block in Ghana, we are seeking a rig and expect to spud by the first quarter of 2011 as well.
Turning to Marketing and Refining, we reported a profit of $87 million for the first quarter of 2010. Financial results at our HOVENSA joint venture were below the year ago quarter primarily due to costs associated with the planned turnaround of the FCC and higher refinery fuel costs. 
Marketing earnings were better than the first quarter last year. Retail marketing gasoline volumes on a per site basis were down 6%, but total convenience store sales were up 8%, due partly to new product offerings.  In Energy Marketing, although there were fewer heating degree days than the year ago quarter, the business delivered strong financial results. While fuel oil and natural gas sales volume declined year-over-year, electricity sales were higher. 
Solid operating performance and improving commodity prices have strengthened our cash and liquidity position. We remain committed to remaining our financial strength so we are positioned to fund our investment opportunities to profitably grow our reserves and production. 
I will now turn the call over to John Reilly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare first quarter 2010 results for the fourth quarter of 2009. First quarter 2010 consolidated results amounted to net income of $538 million compared with $358 million in the fourth quar
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare first quarter 2010 results for the fourth quarter of 2009. 
First quarter 2010 consolidated results amounted to net income of $538 million compared with $358 million in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Exploration and Production. Exploration and Production operations in the first quarter of 2010 had income of $551 million compared with $494 million in the fourth quarter. The first quarter results included after-tax income of $58 million relating to the sale of the Corporation's interest in the Jambi Merang natural gas development project in Indonesia. Excluding the effect of this asset sale, the change in the after-tax components of the results are as follows.  Higher selling prices increased earnings by $48 million. Lower sales volumes decreased earnings by $95 million. Lower costs increased earnings by $48 million. All other items net to a decrease in earnings of $2 million for an overall decrease in first quarter adjusted earnings of $1 million.
Following a large overlift in the fourth quarter of 2009, E&P operations were underlifted compared with production in the first quarter of 2010, which decreased after-tax income by approximately $55 million. The E&P effective income tax rate was 45%.
Turning to Marketing and Refining. Marketing and Refining operations had income of $87 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with income of $17 million in the fourth quarter. 
Refining operations lost $56 million in the first quarter compared with a loss of $40 million in the fourth quarter. The Corporation's share of HOVENSA's results, after income taxes, was a loss of $52 million in the first quarter compared with a loss of $40 million in the fourth quarter.  Port Reading generated a loss of $4 million in the first quarter and broke even in the fourth quarter.
During the first quarter, the planned turnaround of the FCC unit at the HOVENSA refinery in St. Croix was completed and operations re-commenced in March 2010. The Corporation's share of HOVENSA's turnaround expenses in the first quarter was approximately $20 million, after income taxes.  In addition, the scheduled turnaround for the Port Reading refining facility commenced in April and is expected to last approximately 35 days. The estimated after-tax expenses to be recorded in the second quarter for the Port Reading turnaround are approximately $20 million after tax.
Marketing earnings were $121 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with $45 million in the fourth quarter, principally reflecting seasonally higher margins and refined product volumes in energy marketing operations. Trading activities generated income of $22 million in the first quarter compared with income of $12 million in the fourth quarter.
Turning to Corporate. Net Corporate expenses amounted to $48 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with $97 million in the fourth quarter. Net Corporate expenses in the first quarter included an after-tax charge of $7 million for the repurchase of the remaining $116 million of bonds that were scheduled to mature in 2011. Net Corporate expenses in the fourth quarter included an after-tax charge of $34 million for the repurchase of $546 million of the 2011 bonds and $10 million for pension plan settlements related to employee retirements.  Excluding these special charges, net Corporate expenses were lower in the first quarter, primarily due to lower employee-related costs. 
After-tax interest expense was $52 million in the first quarter compared with $56 million in the fourth quarter.
Turning to cash flow. Net cash provided by operating activities in the first quarter, including a decrease of $432 million from changes in working capital, was $825 million. Proceeds from the Jambi Merang asset sale were $183 million. Repayments of debt amounted to $142 million. Capital expenditures were $788 million. All other items amounted to a decrease in cash of $70 million, resulting in a net increase in cash and cash equivalents in the first quarter of $8 million.
We had $1,370 million of cash and cash equivalents at March 31, 2010 and $1,362 million at December 31, 2009. Our available revolving credit capacity was $3 billion at March 31, 2010.  Total debt was $4,335 million at March 31, 2010 and $4,467 million at December 31, 2009. The Corporation's debt-to-capitalization ratio at March 31, 2010 was 23.6% compared with 24.8% at the end of 2009.
This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First just on the Bakken.  I think you mentioned you were up to five rigs so far. Just wondering how you're feeling about how the well costs are coming in and production rates, if there's any update there? And then also, in the Shell area, if there's any
componenttext: First just on the Bakken.  I think you mentioned you were up to five rigs so far. Just wondering how you're feeling about how the well costs are coming in and production rates, if there's any update there? And then also, in the Shell area, if there's any update on where you are in the Marcellus program?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Bakken first, yes, we have five rigs operating. We've got four dual lateral wells that we've completed to date. And while it's still early days, the results are coming in as expected on those wells. So the well cost for those dual-laterals are aver
componenttext: On the Bakken first, yes, we have five rigs operating. We've got four dual lateral wells that we've completed to date. And while it's still early days, the results are coming in as expected on those wells. So the well cost for those dual-laterals are averaging $10 million to $11 million each. The EUR is about a million barrels per well. And the 30-day average IP for those dual-laterals is around 1,000 barrels a day. So that's 450 to 500 barrels per lateral. If I turn to the Marcellus, again we're continuing to build our position in the Marcellus. We are at about 80,000 net acres now in the Marcellus, primarily in Wayne County, Pennsylvania. About 50,000 of that is Hess-operated and the balance is part of this joint venture we have with Newfield. Our plans this year are to drill five to ten wells during the second half of 2010 in order to evaluate the resource potential on the acreage.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Pony eastern flank extension, if that does come in, order of magnitude of what it might mean for Pony. 100 million barrels? 50? 100?  Something along those lines in terms of additional reserve potential?
componenttext: On the Pony eastern flank extension, if that does come in, order of magnitude of what it might mean for Pony. 100 million barrels? 50? 100?  Something along those lines in terms of additional reserve potential?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a little background first on Pony 3. As John said in his opening remarks, it's an appraisal well on our 100% owned Block 469, and it's really designed to delineate the Pony reservoir on the  eastern extension under the block. Now the results of
componenttext: Yes, just a little background first on Pony 3. As John said in his opening remarks, it's an appraisal well on our 100% owned Block 469, and it's really designed to delineate the Pony reservoir on the  eastern extension under the block. Now the results of that well are going to be used to determine the final equity split in this combined Pony/Knotty Head joint development. I can't give any volume estimates. It's just way too early. I mean, we're only at 25,000 feet in the well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: You're doing your extension. I think they're drilling their Knotty Head No. 2.  And maybe after those two wells, one from each of you, we can then get a unitization and some sort of an agreement on the split?

componenttext: No. If you're referring to from the working capital discussion, no. We just had a decrease in working capital in the quarter of $430 million. Our cash flow was quite strong from our operations. So from that standpoint, there's nothing per say from a deferred tax aspect. So if you remove the working capital, our cash flow would have been above $1.250 billion in the first quarter.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Mark. Let me just kind of give a broad update about Australia. So we are completing, as we speak, our 12th well. So this will be the 12th of 16 commitment wells. Of those 12, we've had 10 discoveries so far. We plan to finish out drilling tho
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Mark. Let me just kind of give a broad update about Australia. So we are completing, as we speak, our 12th well. So this will be the 12th of 16 commitment wells. Of those 12, we've had 10 discoveries so far. We plan to finish out drilling those 16 commitment wells by mid year. And then after that, we'll follow with an appraisal and flow testing phase during the second half. Now as we've said before, we don't plan to give resource estimates until our drilling programs are complete. On the commercialization side, we are continuing again in parallel to work various commercial options with all the potential partners.

componenttext: Greg, the exploration expenditure in the quarter,  the run rate obviously [indiscernible]  $50 million kind of level, but there's not a whole lot of exploration activity going on. Can you just kind of tell us, what exactly are you doing right now in terms of fleshing out the program?  What exactly are you spending on right now? And if you could give us an update on the well program for the balance of this year, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico. I think you talked about possibly drilling two unnamed prospects at some point?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The majority of our spend in exploration, as you know, is in Australia. So that's both on our 390 Block and also the 404 Block with Woodside. As we move forward, where is our exploration spend going to move to.  John mentioned in his opening remarks, of c
componenttext: The majority of our spend in exploration, as you know, is in Australia. So that's both on our 390 Block and also the 404 Block with Woodside. As we move forward, where is our exploration spend going to move to.  John mentioned in his opening remarks, of course, Ghana. We're out contracting a rig for Ghana.  We expect to spud the first well early 2011. We've also entered a rig-sharing agreement with Murphy in Indonesia. So we anticipate drilling Semai early 2011, maybe we can squeeze it in in late 2010. And then as we move further into 2011, of course, Australia continues with appraisal and follow up. And then the Stena IV, after she finishes Pony 3, will then begin an exploration program in the Gulf of Mexico. So the plans are she will stay in the Gulf and just continue an exploration program.  So that's a little color on where it's headed.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: How do you identify the prospects in the Gulf, Greg?
componenttext: How do you identify the prospects in the Gulf, Greg?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the final one for me is, if we look at the last quarter, you had some issues around the JDA in terms of delivering gas that had been previously paid for. Is that process now complete or can you just give us an update as to where you stand in thos
componenttext: And then the final one for me is, if we look at the last quarter, you had some issues around the JDA in terms of delivering gas that had been previously paid for. Is that process now complete or can you just give us an update as to where you stand in those deliveries?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The take-or-pay, it's not an issue of deliverability from the JDA. It's a take-or-pay contract. So what had happened early in the field due to getting the pipelines online a little bit late, the buyers were required to pay us for gas that wasn't delivered
componenttext: The take-or-pay, it's not an issue of deliverability from the JDA. It's a take-or-pay contract. So what had happened early in the field due to getting the pipelines online a little bit late, the buyers were required to pay us for gas that wasn't delivered. So we recorded a take-or-pay liability, if you want to say "deferred revenues". And what happens is when the buyers take gas above a contractual nomination amount, they eat back into that take-or-pay liability. And it goes back, if you remember in the fourth quarter, what happens is they get it at the prices that were in effect during that time period. So that's why, from a revenue standpoint, we showed a lower realization at the JDA. We still do have about 18 bcf, I think, left in our take-or-pay liability. So we still have deferred revenues up on our books, and that will continue to come down as the buyers take additional gas above the contracted amount.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on your volumes and volume guidance.  I think what you were saying is that there obviously is the issue of the disposals. But I was still surprised given the run rate that you're achieving in this quarter that you would be retaining the full year gui
componenttext: Just on your volumes and volume guidance.  I think what you were saying is that there obviously is the issue of the disposals. But I was still surprised given the run rate that you're achieving in this quarter that you would be retaining the full year guidance in the previous range. I'm just wondering, first, did I miss something on disposals or other reasons why you're doing that? And secondly, if you could add anything else as to how you get to that full year number from what was obviously a strong Q1?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we were happy with our first quarter production performance. And so, I'll come back to the asset trades. I mean, normally for Hess, as you move throughout the year and you get to the second quarter, and particularly in the third quarter, our vo
componenttext: Obviously, we were happy with our first quarter production performance. And so, I'll come back to the asset trades. I mean, normally for Hess, as you move throughout the year and you get to the second quarter, and particularly in the third quarter, our volumes are always decreased typically due to the shutdowns in the U.K. and normal maintenance that is happening across the globe. So we always come in stronger in the first quarter and then dip down. On top of that, we have these asset trades.  So as John has mentioned, the U.K. gas assets, as well is our trade with Shell, are expected to be completed in the second half of the year, which will cause our production to decrease by approximately 5,000 barrels a day. So at this point here, from our stronger performance, we are not changing our guidance that we went out earlier in the year with. So we are reflecting some of that stronger performance, but we are keeping our guidance at 400 to 410.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.  But I guess it's a conservative number, isn't it?
componenttext: Yes.  But I guess it's a conservative number, isn't it?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I mean again, we'll continue to update everyone as we go throughout the year. But we feel comfortable with that forecast range.
componenttext: No. I mean again, we'll continue to update everyone as we go throughout the year. But we feel comfortable with that forecast range.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could continue on the guidance a little bit, please.  I think you mentioned $1.250 as your underlying cash flow from operations? Was there anything one-off about that number? I'm thinking about tax rates or anything else that might have boosted t
componenttext: And if I could continue on the guidance a little bit, please.  I think you mentioned $1.250 as your underlying cash flow from operations? Was there anything one-off about that number? I'm thinking about tax rates or anything else that might have boosted that. And the extension is that we heard about under $80 barrell of oil here and you're well in excess in terms of cash flows above CapEx and dividends. Could you just address how you intend to utilize that excess cash over the course of the year? My guidance is the CapEx number is $4.1 billion. Anything you can add on dividend policy of that paydown will be great?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let me start with your first question, were there one-offs in the quarter.  So cash flow from operating activities, and I'm excluding working capital, it was as you said $1.250 billion. There we're no real one-offs in there. You were asking about the t
componenttext: So let me start with your first question, were there one-offs in the quarter.  So cash flow from operating activities, and I'm excluding working capital, it was as you said $1.250 billion. There we're no real one-offs in there. You were asking about the tax rate, and if you're looking at our press release just from the E&P earnings, which includes the special, you'll see a tax rate around 40% for the group.  However, that includes a special item on the Jambi Merang sale, and that sale, due to that it was a share sale, did not have tax associated with it. So our run rate for the first quarter, excluding the special, was 45%. A little below our guidance, but basically really no one-offs in the first quarter from a cash flow standpoint. As you're going forward through the year, it's early in the year right now, so we have that guidance at $4.1 billion. You'll always have things that move in, move out of our CapEx profile. At this point, we will update. It is our plan to update on the second quarter conference call on where our CapEx is going.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.  And I guess what I was driving at is that you're generating excess cash. Would you be pushing CapEx up?  Would you be pushing dividend up? Would you be pushing debt down, as a general?
componenttext: Okay.  And I guess what I was driving at is that you're generating excess cash. Would you be pushing CapEx up?  Would you be pushing dividend up? Would you be pushing debt down, as a general?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, Paul, the priority for our cash flow is to grow our reserves and production profitably. Our CapEx program reflects that.  At the middle of the year, we'll be giving an update on that CapEx program. And it's a little hard now and inappropriate
componenttext: As you know, Paul, the priority for our cash flow is to grow our reserves and production profitably. Our CapEx program reflects that.  At the middle of the year, we'll be giving an update on that CapEx program. And it's a little hard now and inappropriate now to get ahead of ourselves. So the first call on cash is CapEx and then maintaining the company's financial strength for future investments.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Neil McMahon from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Back again to Australia, obviously you're looking at the best ways to commercialize the acreage there. Have you done any thinking as to whether it could be an outright exit out of Australia having done extremely well in the exploration program, or are you
componenttext: Back again to Australia, obviously you're looking at the best ways to commercialize the acreage there. Have you done any thinking as to whether it could be an outright exit out of Australia having done extremely well in the exploration program, or are you looking at trying to get some sort of partnership in the LNG schemes that are going on, particularly with Woodside? if you could give us any color on that? And secondly, just really any update on Libya and offshore. Have you had any interest from any of the bigger companies in terms of farming into your discovery there? Or any updates in terms of how your geological, geophysical studies are going?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, let me address Australia. Our intention is to commercialize those resources. So that is our primary intention. As I've said earlier, we're working with three different parties down there. We've made no decisions on what liquefaction
componenttext: I think, first of all, let me address Australia. Our intention is to commercialize those resources. So that is our primary intention. As I've said earlier, we're working with three different parties down there. We've made no decisions on what liquefaction route we're going to take because we are still in  commercial discussions and we want to make sure we understand all the resources on the block before we make any decisions. In regards to Libya, recall we had two successful flow tests on the Libyan Block and right now we are currently on a joint feasibility study with the NOC, which concludes development plans and commercial terms. So that's kind of where we are on Libya right now.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: And any interest from other players in getting involved with you in Libya?

componenttextpreview: We've had companies approach us. We've made no decisions on involving others in Libya at this point.
componenttext: We've had companies approach us. We've made no decisions on involving others in Libya at this point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, I might be getting too granular on the Bakken rate of change over just three months, but I wanted to get a view points of clarification there. It looks like you're about 13,000 barrels a day now on the Bakken versus about 10,000 barrels a day about
componenttext: Greg, I might be getting too granular on the Bakken rate of change over just three months, but I wanted to get a view points of clarification there. It looks like you're about 13,000 barrels a day now on the Bakken versus about 10,000 barrels a day about three months ago, which seems like a pretty good clip of growth given, I think, your full-year guidance for about 4,000 to 5,000 barrels a day of growth in the Bakken. Is it outperforming your expectations, and as a result is there some upside to that full-year expectation?  And then just kind of looking at your quotes on the four dual-laterals completed to date, all that's about the same number you had in January. And with five rigs running and I thought the bulk of the development activity dedicated to the dual lateral completion technique now, just wondering if maybe you've got a few wells now queued up awaiting completion that have been drilled, or again, maybe I'm splitting hairs. But just any more color trying to help me fit those  pieces together, if you don't mind.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the production rate first, we are essentially on plan and we're sticking with our 20,000 barrel-a-day production rate at exit rate for the year. So no change there. Regarding your questions about the wells, I think probably what I said on the last c
componenttext: So on the production rate first, we are essentially on plan and we're sticking with our 20,000 barrel-a-day production rate at exit rate for the year. So no change there. Regarding your questions about the wells, I think probably what I said on the last call is that we drilled four wells. We've actually drilled nine dual-laterals now. We just have completed four. So they're in various phases of completion.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe a broader question on the Bakken and following up on  some of your previous comments on the dual-laterals on whether you envision any change in the type of wells that you'll be drilling as you ramp activity. Maybe for a lack of a better term, reserv
componenttext: Maybe a broader question on the Bakken and following up on  some of your previous comments on the dual-laterals on whether you envision any change in the type of wells that you'll be drilling as you ramp activity. Maybe for a lack of a better term, reservoir characterization mode to a manufacturing mode, meaning is there going to be change from dual lateral to a single lateral. And then secondly, and somewhat related, I know in your last call, you referenced long-term Bakken service contracts as more imminent. Has anything been awarded there, any cost advantage of a lockup?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So where are we on the drilling? So our current base plan is to utilize the dual lateral across most of our Phase I acreage. And that's because the middle Bakken and Three Forks are largely present across that Phase I acreage. Now the cost advantage is if
componenttext: So where are we on the drilling? So our current base plan is to utilize the dual lateral across most of our Phase I acreage. And that's because the middle Bakken and Three Forks are largely present across that Phase I acreage. Now the cost advantage is if approach is clear. You get one left vertical wellbore.  You have fewer down hole equipment.  You have fewer surface facilities.  So we really believe that this dual lateral approach, combined with the application [indiscernible] manufacturing techniques and pad drilling, is going to result in superior returns for us on the Bakken, which is why we're going with that approach. Now I will say its early days.  As we learn, as we need to, we'll change and modify as appropriate.   But right now we're happy with the dual lateral performance.

componenttext: And any update on the long-term service contracts?

componenttext: Well, I think we're encouraged that the governments are talking and really seem intent on settling this issue finally.  There's a partner meeting at the end of the month with the operator at the end of next month  to talk about the go-forward plan.  So that's really all I can say at this point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on Ghana. Obviously, a small dryhole for [indiscernible].  I mean, does that change anything in terms of your view of your acreage there?  And a follow-up on the Bakken in terms of have there been any kind of variation in the well results in earl
componenttext: Question on Ghana. Obviously, a small dryhole for [indiscernible].  I mean, does that change anything in terms of your view of your acreage there?  And a follow-up on the Bakken in terms of have there been any kind of variation in the well results in early days from region to region? And perhaps some commentary on the discounts that you think you'll get from the Bakken relative to WTI, really driven by the ability to get the crude oil out of the region?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. The discounts I'll go with first and then Gregg will pick up on the other questions  you asked.  Currently, the discounts have widened a little by about $2 off the WTI, so it's about $4 going to $6  range, about. And that's because of the Mandan  tur
componenttext: Yes. The discounts I'll go with first and then Gregg will pick up on the other questions  you asked.  Currently, the discounts have widened a little by about $2 off the WTI, so it's about $4 going to $6  range, about. And that's because of the Mandan  turnaround and work that's going on there. We can't predict differentials, what WTI is going to do, but we see that narrowing back. So the pricing that we've gotten in the past, for at least the next year going forward, we think that will hold for the increase in our Bakken. So anywhere from $2 to $6, let's call it a $4 average.  That's a guesstimate at best. But I'm just trying to give you a feel that while the discounts have widened out in the last month or so, we expect them to come back once Mandan is back on stream. That's number one.  Number two, as the volumes go up, we're going to continue to look at different evacuation routes to maximum value and it would be premature now to say what those numbers are.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the variation, has there been any variation as you've drilled in different areas across the Bakken acreage that you've observed so far?  Good wells, bad wells?
componenttext: And in terms of the variation, has there been any variation as you've drilled in different areas across the Bakken acreage that you've observed so far?  Good wells, bad wells?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ed.  So on the Bakken, it's a statistical play. So you are going to have variation in new wells. We forecast on the probabilistic basis for the Bakken, and we are will within the  range. So we're  not seeing anything. We're not being surprised by any
componenttext: Yes, Ed.  So on the Bakken, it's a statistical play. So you are going to have variation in new wells. We forecast on the probabilistic basis for the Bakken, and we are will within the  range. So we're  not seeing anything. We're not being surprised by anything. You had a second question about --

componenttext: Paul, we're actually in a balanced position, I'm going to call from an overall inventory position, across our assets. There obviously are some assets that have a little higher inventory and some of it a bit below, but if you're going quarter-by-quarter average, we feel we're in a pretty balanced position. So it shouldn't be a material under or overlift occurring, let's say, in the next quarter. There will always be small ups and downs though.

componenttext: And also, previously you have given the unique cost guidance for the year, for cash and DD&A with [indiscernible] and everything going on. Is there any update or change in those numbers?

componenttext: No, we're not changing our guidance related to that. So with the U.K. tax asset sale and with the Valhall trade. We still have cash costs at $15 to $16 for the year and DD&A at $14.50 to $15.50 for the year. And then we'll update our guidance, as we said,  just like on CapEx, in the middle of the year.

componenttextpreview: Just a point of clarification. I thought I understood that Ghana was previously scheduled for second half of the year 2010. So I'm just trying to  to confirm. Has that been pushed to the right a bit first quarter of '11, and if so, can you explain what th
componenttext: Just a point of clarification. I thought I understood that Ghana was previously scheduled for second half of the year 2010. So I'm just trying to  to confirm. Has that been pushed to the right a bit first quarter of '11, and if so, can you explain what the driver is there?

componenttextpreview: No, it hasn't.  I think the last time what we said is that we would drill the well in early 2011, that there was a possibility that we could squeeze it in at the end of 2010. It's really going to depend on  rig availability. We're out to tender with three
componenttext: No, it hasn't.  I think the last time what we said is that we would drill the well in early 2011, that there was a possibility that we could squeeze it in at the end of 2010. It's really going to depend on  rig availability. We're out to tender with three separate companies right now to get a slot for the Ghana well. So that's what's driving the timing, is just the slot timing.

componenttext: And then the only other question I had for you, is it just premature, I know you're kind of getting  ramped up in the Marcellus and the Bakken continues to ramp up, but with regard to international opportunities, is that something that's on the radar screen at this point, or are you really just trying to focus on your expertise in the U.S. right now?

componenttext: No, I think as we've said before, we are looking at international opportunities and unconventional, but  just not prepared to talk about that right now as to what we're specifically looking at. But we are looking.
