headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Meg and I will be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. We will conduct a question-and
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Meg and I will be your operator for today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. We will conduct a question-and-answer session towards the end of this conference. (Operator Instructions). As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Jay Wilson, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Meg, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections and
componenttext:
Thank you, Meg, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements.
With me today are John Hess, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; Greg Hill, President, Worldwide Exploration and Production; and John Rielly, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
I'll now turn the call over to John Hess.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay and welcome to our first quarter conference call. I will make a few brief comments after which John Rielly will review our financial results.Net income for the first quarter of 2010 was $538 million versus a loss of $59 million a year ago
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay and welcome to our first quarter conference call. I will make a few brief comments after which John Rielly will review our financial results.
Net income for the first quarter of 2010 was $538 million versus a loss of $59 million a year ago. Our earnings were positively impacted by higher crude oil and natural gas selling prices and production volumes that more than offset the impact of weaker refining results.
Exploration and Production earned $551 million. Crude oil and natural gas production averaged 423,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was 8% above the year ago quarter. This increase resulted primarily from higher production from the Shenzi and Conger Fields in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico and the JDA in the Gulf of Thailand.
In January, we closed the previously announced sale of our Jambi Merang asset in Indonesia receiving proceeds of $183 million. At the end of March we announced the sale of a package of mature, non-operated natural gas production and transportation assets in the UK North Sea for $423 million. The sale, which is expected to close in the third quarter, is part of the company's ongoing portfolio management efforts.
We also continue to make progress in finalizing our previously announced strategic asset trade with Shell, which is now expected to close in the second half of this year. In this trade, Hess will assume Shell's 28.09% interest in the Valhall field and 25% interest in the satellite Hod field in Norway. In return, Shell will assume Hess's 9.29% interest in the Clair field, in the United Kingdom and all of Hess' interests in Gabon.
Although the net effect of these asset sales and the strategic asset trade with Shell is to reduce full year 2010 production by approximately 5,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, our 2010 production forecast remains at 400,000 to 410,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day.
In North Dakota, net production from the Bakken reached 13,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in March. We currently have five rigs dedicated to drilling Bakken wells and we plan to add five additional rigs over the next 12 months. With regard to exploration, drilling is continuing on permits WA-390-P and WA-404-P in the North West Shelf of Australia. Also, discussions with potential partners regarding the commercialization of natural gas resources on our 100% owned WA-390-P block are ongoing.
In February we spud the Pony No. 3 well on Green Canyon 469 in which Hess has a 100% working interest. This well which is still drilling, is designed to test the eastern extent of the Pony structure. Due to a previous farmed out agreement regarding the Stena Forth drill ship, we plan to release the rig in early June to another operator and then bring it back to finish drilling the well in the fourth quarter.
In Brazil, the operator of Block BM-S-22 is in the process of completing the analysis of seismic, log and core data and plans to drill a third well in the second half of 2010. Hess has a 40% working interest in the block. And Indonesia, we have secured a rig to drill the Semai V prospect in which Hess has a 100% working interest. This well is expected to spud by the first quarter of 2011. With regard to our Deepwater Tano Cape Three Points Block in Ghana, we are seeking a rig and expect to spud the first as well by the first quarter of 2011 as well.
Turning to marketing and refining, we reported a profit of $87 million for the first quarter of 2010. Financial results at our HOVENSA joint venture were below the year ago quarter primarily due to costs associated with the planned turnaround of the FCC and higher refinery costs.
Marketing earnings were better than the first quarter last year. Retail marketing gasoline volumes on a per site basis were down 6%, but total convenience store sales were up 8%, due partly to new product offerings. 
In Energy Marketing, although there were fewer heating degree days than the year ago quarter, the business delivered strong financial results. While fuel oil and natural gas sales volumes declined year-over-year, electricity sales were higher.
Solid operating performance and improving commodity prices have strengthened our cash and liquidity position. We remain committed to maintaining our financial strength, so we are positioned to fund our investment opportunities to profitably grow our reserves and production. I will now turn the call over to John Rielly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Hello everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare first quarter 2010 results to the fourth quarter of 2009. First quarter 2010 consolidated results amounted to net income of $538 million compared with $358 million in the fourth quarter.
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Hello everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare first quarter 2010 results to the fourth quarter of 2009. First quarter 2010 consolidated results amounted to net income of $538 million compared with $358 million in the fourth quarter.
Turning to Exploration and Production, Exploration and Production operations in the first quarter of 2010 had income of $551 million compared with $494 million in the fourth quarter. The first quarter results included after-tax income of $58 million relating to the sale of the Corporation's interest in the Jambi Merang natural gas development project in Indonesia. Excluding the effect of this asset sale, the change in the after-tax components of the results are as follows.
Higher selling prices increased earnings by $48 million. Lower sales volumes decreased earnings by$ 95 million. Lower costs increased earnings by $48 million. All other items net to a decrease in earnings of $2 million for an overall decrease in first quarter adjusted earnings of $1 million.
Following a large overlift in the fourth quarter of 2009, E&P operations were underlifted compared with production in the first quarter of 2010, which decreased after-tax income by approximately $55 million. The E&P effective income tax rate was 45%.
Turning to Marketing and Refining, Marketing and Refining operations had income of $87 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with income of $17 million in the fourth quarter. Refining operations lost $56 million in the first quarter compared with a loss of $40 million in the fourth quarter. The Corporation's share of HOVENSA's results, after income taxes, was a loss of $52 million in the first quarter compared with a loss of $40 million in the fourth quarter. Port Reading generated a loss of $4 million in the first quarter and broke even in the fourth quarter.
During the first quarter, the planned turnaround of the FCC unit at the HOVENSA refinery in St. Croix was completed and operations recommenced in March 2010. The Corporation's share of HOVENSA's turnaround expenses in the first quarter was approximately $20 million after income taxes.
In addition, the scheduled turnaround for the Port Reading refining facility commenced in April and is expected to last approximately 35 days. The estimated after-tax expenses to be recorded in the second quarter for the Port Reading turnaround are approximately $20 million after-tax.
Marketing earnings were $121 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with $45 million in the fourth quarter, principally reflecting seasonally higher margins and refined product volumes in energy marketing operations. Trading activities generated income of $22 million in the first quarter compared with income of $12 million in the fourth quarter.
Turning to Corporate, net Corporate expenses amounted to $48 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with $97 million in the fourth quarter. Net Corporate expenses in the first quarter included an after-tax charge of $7 million for the repurchase of the remaining $116 million of bonds that were scheduled to mature in 2011.
Net Corporate expenses in the fourth quarter included an after-tax charge of $34 million for the repurchase of $546 million of the 2011 bonds and $10 million for pension plan settlements related to employee retirements. Excluding these special charges, net Corporate expenses were lower in the first quarter, primarily due to lower employee-related costs. After-tax interest expense was $52 million in the first quarter compared with $56 million in the fourth quarter.
Turning to cash flow, net cash provided by operating activities in the first quarter, including a decrease of $432 million from changes in working capital, was $825 million, Proceeds from the Jambi Merang asset sale were $183 million. Repayments of debt amounted to $142 million. Capital expenditures were $788 million. All other items amounted to a decrease in cash of $70 million, resulting in a net increase in cash and cash equivalents in the first quarter of $8 million.
We had $1.370 billion of cash and cash equivalents at March 31, 2010 and $1.362 billion at December 31, 2009. Our available revolving credit capacity was $3 billion at March 31, 2010. Total debt was $4.335 billion at March 31, 2010 and $4.467 billion at December 31, 2009. The Corporation's debt to capitalization ratio at March 31, 2010 was 23.6% compared with 24.8% at the end of 2009.
This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Bakken first, yes, we have five rigs operating. We've got four dual lateral wells that we've completed to-date, and while it's still early days, results are coming in as expected on those wells. So, the well costs for those dual laterals were avera
componenttext:
On the Bakken first, yes, we have five rigs operating. We've got four dual lateral wells that we've completed to-date, and while it's still early days, results are coming in as expected on those wells. So, the well costs for those dual laterals were averaging $10 million to $11 million each. The EUR is about one million barrels per well and the 30 day average IP for those dual laterals is around the 1000 barrels a day, so that's 450 to 500 barrels per lateral. 
If I turn to the Marcellus again, we're continuing to build our position in the Marcellus. We're at about 80,000 net acres now in the Marcellus, primarily in Wayne County, Pennsylvania. About 50,000 of that is Hess operated and the balance is part of this joint venture we have with Newfield. Our plan this year are to drill five to 10 wells during the second half of 2010 in order to evaluate the resource potential on the acreage.

componenttext: Yes, just a little background first on Pony 3. As John said in his opening remarks, it's an appraisal well on our 100% owned Block 469. It's really designed to delineate Pony reservoir on the eastern extension under the block. Now, the result for that well is going to be used to determine the final equity split in this combined Pony, (inaudible) joint development. Can't give any volume estimate, it's just way too early. I mean we are only at 25,000 feet in the well.

componenttext:
Let me just kind of give a broad update about Australia. So we are completing, as we speak, our 12th well. So this will be the 12th of 16 commitment wells. Of those 12, we've had 10 discovery so far. We plan to finish out drilling those 16 commitment wells by midyear and then after that we'll follow with an appraisal and blow testing phase during the second half. 
Now, as we've said before, we don't plan to give resource estimates until our drilling programs are complete. On the commercialization side, we're continuing again in parallel the work you know various commercial options with all the potential partners.

componenttext: A couple of diverse questions from me also. Greg, the exploration expenditure in the quarter is - the run rate, obviously, sticks in that $150 million level, but there is not a whole lot of exploration activity going on. Can you just tell us what exactly are you doing right now in terms of fleshing out the program? What exactly are you spending on right now? And if you could give us an update on the well program for the balance of this year, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico, I think you had talked about possibly drilling two unnamed prospects at some point?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The majority of our spends in exploration, as you know, is in Australia. So that's both on our 390 Block and also the 404 Block with Woodside. As we move forward, where is our exploration spend going to move to, John mentioned in his opening remarks, of c
componenttext:
The majority of our spends in exploration, as you know, is in Australia. So that's both on our 390 Block and also the 404 Block with Woodside. As we move forward, where is our exploration spend going to move to, John mentioned in his opening remarks, of course, Ghana, we're contracting a rig for Ghana. We expect to spud the first well early 2011. We've also entered a rig sharing agreement with Murphy in Indonesia. 
So we anticipate drilling Semai early 2011, maybe we can squeeze it in, in late 2010. And then, as we move further into 2011, of course, Australia continues with appraisal and follow-up. And then the Stena Forth, after she finishes Pony 3, we'll then begin an exploration program in the Gulf of Mexico. So plans are she will stay in the Gulf and just continue an exploration program. So that's just a little color on where it's headed.

componenttext: And the final one for me is, if we look at the last quarter you had some issues around the JDA in terms of delivering gas that had been previously paid for. Is that process now complete or can you just give us update as to where you stand in those deliveries?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The take-or-pay, it's not an issue of deliverability from the JDA. It's a take-or-pay contract. So, what had happened early in the field due to getting the pipelines online a little bit late, the buyers were required to pay us for debt that wasn't deliver
componenttext:
The take-or-pay, it's not an issue of deliverability from the JDA. It's a take-or-pay contract. So, what had happened early in the field due to getting the pipelines online a little bit late, the buyers were required to pay us for debt that wasn't delivered. So, we recorded a take-or-pay liability, if you want to say deferred revenues, and what happens is when the buyers take gas above a contractual nomination amount, they eat back into that take or pay liability. 
If you remember in the fourth quarter, what happens is they get it at the prices that were in a factor in that time period. So, that's why from a revenue standpoint we showed a lower realization at the JDA. We still do have about 18 BCF I think left in our take or pay liability. So we have still have deferred revenues up on our books and that will continue to come down as the buyers take additional gas above the contracted amount.

componenttext: Just on your volumes and volumes guidance, would you mind, I did drop off the call for a second, so please forgive me if this is a repeated question that you've addressed, but I think what you were saying is that there obviously is the issue of the disposals. But I was still surprised given the run rate that you are achieving in this quarter that you would be retaining the full year guidance in the previous range. I'm just wondering firstly, did I miss something on disposals or other reasons why you are doing that? And secondly, if you could add anything else as to how you get to that full year number from what was obviously a strong Q1?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we were happy with our first quarter production performance. I'll come back to the asset trades. Normally for Hess, as you move throughout the year, and you get to the second quarter and particularly in the third quarter, our volumes always dec
componenttext:
Obviously, we were happy with our first quarter production performance. I'll come back to the asset trades. Normally for Hess, as you move throughout the year, and you get to the second quarter and particularly in the third quarter, our volumes always decrease typically due to the shutdowns in the UK and normal maintenance that's happening across the globe. So we always come in stronger in the first quarter and then get down. On top of that, we have these asset trades. 
So, as John Hess mentioned, the UK gas assets as well as our trade with Shell are expected to be completed in the second half of the year, which will cause our production to decrease by approximately 5,000 barrels a day. So, at this point here, from our stronger performance, we are not changing our guidance that we went out earlier in the year with. So we are reflecting some of that stronger performance, but we're keeping our guidance at 400 to 410.

componenttext: And if I could continue on the guidance a little bit, please, I think you mentioned $1.250 is your underlying cash flow from operations, was there anything one-off about that number? I'm thinking about tax rates or anything else that might have boosted that. And the extension is that we were under $80 barrel of oil here and you are well in excess in terms of cash flows above CapEx and dividends. Could you just address how you intend to utilize that excess cash over the course of the year? My guidance CapEx number is $4.1 billion. Anything you could add on dividend policy or debt paydown, it would be great?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your first question, where there one-offs in the quarter? Cash flow from operating activities excluding working capital, it was, as you said, $1.250 billion. There were no real one-offs in there. You're asking about the tax rate, and if
componenttext:
Let me start with your first question, where there one-offs in the quarter? Cash flow from operating activities excluding working capital, it was, as you said, $1.250 billion. There were no real one-offs in there. You're asking about the tax rate, and if you're looking at our press release just from the E&P earnings which include this special, you'll see a tax rate around 40% for the Group. 
However, that includes the special item on the Jambi Merang sale due to that, it was a share sale, did not have tax associated with it. So our run rate for the first quarter excluding the special was 45%, a little below our guidance, but basically, really, no one-offs in the first quarter from a cash flow standpoint. Then, as you are going forward through the year, it's early in the year right now, so we have that guidance at $4.1 billion. We always have things that move in and move out of our CapEx profile. At this point, we will update and it is our plan to update on the second quarter conference call on where our CapEx is going.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess what I was driving at is that you are generating excess cash, would you be pushing CapEx up, would be pushing dividend up, would you be pushing debt down?
componenttext: And I guess what I was driving at is that you are generating excess cash, would you be pushing CapEx up, would be pushing dividend up, would you be pushing debt down?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, Paul, the priority of our cash flow is to grow our reserves and production profitably. Our CapEx program reflects that. At the middle of the year, we'll be giving an update on that CapEx program, and it's a little hard now and inappropriate n
componenttext: As you know, Paul, the priority of our cash flow is to grow our reserves and production profitably. Our CapEx program reflects that. At the middle of the year, we'll be giving an update on that CapEx program, and it's a little hard now and inappropriate now to get ahead of ourselves. So, the first call on cash is CapEx, and then maintaining the company's financial strength for future investment.

And secondly, just really any update on Libya and offshore, have you had any interest from any of the bigger companies in terms of farming in to your discoveries there or any updates in terms of how your geological geophysical studies are going?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, let me address Australia. Our intention is to commercialize those resources, so that is our primary intention. As I said earlier, we're working with three different parties down there. We've have made no decisions on which liquefaction route
componenttext: First of all, let me address Australia. Our intention is to commercialize those resources, so that is our primary intention. As I said earlier, we're working with three different parties down there. We've have made no decisions on which liquefaction route we're going to take because we're still in commercial discussions, and we want to make sure we understand all the resources on the block before we make any decisions. In regards to Libya, recall we had two successful flow test on the Libyan block, and right now, we're currently on a joint feasibility study with the NOC, which includes development plans and commercial terms. So that's where we are on Libya right now.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, I might be getting too granular on the Bakken rate of change over just three months, but wanted to get a few points of clarification there. It looks like you are about 13,000 barrels a day now in the Bakken versus about 10,000 barrels a day about th
componenttext:
Greg, I might be getting too granular on the Bakken rate of change over just three months, but wanted to get a few points of clarification there. It looks like you are about 13,000 barrels a day now in the Bakken versus about 10,000 barrels a day about three months ago, which seems like a pretty good clip of growth, given I think your full year guidance for about 4,000 to 5,000 barrels a day of growth in the Bakken. Is it outperforming your expectations, and as a result, is there some upside to that full year expectation? 
And then, just looking at your quotes on the four dual laterals completed to-date, thought that's about the same number you had in January. And with five rigs running, and I thought the bulk of the development activity dedicated to the dual lateral completion technique now, just wondering if maybe you've got a few wells now queued up awaiting completion that have been drilled, or again, maybe I'm splitting hairs, but just any more color, trying to help me fit those pieces together, if you don't mind?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No problem. So, on the production rate, first, we're essentially on plan and we're sticking with our 20,000 barrel a day production exit rate for the year, so no change there. Regarding your questions about the wells, I think probably what I said on the l
componenttext: No problem. So, on the production rate, first, we're essentially on plan and we're sticking with our 20,000 barrel a day production exit rate for the year, so no change there. Regarding your questions about the wells, I think probably what I said on the last call is that we drilled four wells. We've actually drilled nine dual laterals now, we just have completed four. So they are in various phases of completion.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Maybe a broader question on the Bakken and following up on some of your previous comments on the dual laterals on whether you envision any change in the type of wells that you will be drilling as you ramp activity. Maybe from a lack of a better term, reservoir characterization mode to a manufacturing mode, meaning is there going to be change from the dual lateral to a single lateral? And then, secondly and somewhat related, I know on your last call you had referenced long-term Bakken service contracts as more imminent. Has anything been awarded there? Can we talk about any cost advantage with the lock up?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, where are we on the drilling? Our current base plan is to utilize the dual laterals across most of our phase one acreage, and that's because the Middle Bakken and Three Forks are largely present across that phase one acreage. Now, the cost advantage o
componenttext:
So, where are we on the drilling? Our current base plan is to utilize the dual laterals across most of our phase one acreage, and that's because the Middle Bakken and Three Forks are largely present across that phase one acreage. Now, the cost advantage of this approach is clear. 
You get one less vertical wellbore, you have fewer downhole equipment, you have fewer surface facility. So, we really believe that there is dual lateral approach combined with the application of lean manufacturing techniques and pad drilling is going to result in superior returns for us on the Bakken, which is why we're going with that approach. Now, we'll say its early days. As we learn, as we need to, we'll change and modify as appropriate. But right now, we're happy with dual lateral performance.

componenttext: I guess a question on Ghana, obviously, a small dry hole for Tullow; does that change anything in terms of your view of your acreage there? A follow up on the Bakken in terms of, has there been any variation in the well resource - early days from region-to-region, and perhaps some commentary on the discounts that you think you'll get for the Bakken relative to WTI, really driven by the ability to get the crude oil out of the region.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll go with first, and then Greg will pick up on the other questions you asked. Currently, the discounts have widened a little bit by about $2 off of WTI, so it's like $4 going to $6 range about. And that's because of demand and turnaround and work that'
componenttext:
I'll go with first, and then Greg will pick up on the other questions you asked. Currently, the discounts have widened a little bit by about $2 off of WTI, so it's like $4 going to $6 range about. And that's because of demand and turnaround and work that's going on there. We can't predict differentials what WTI is going to do, but we see that narrowing back. So, the pricing that we've gotten in the past for at least the next year going forward we think that will hold for the increase in our Bakken. 
So, anywhere from $2 to $6, let's go with $4 average. That's a guesstimated best. But I'm just trying to give you a feel that while the discounts have widened out in the last month or so, we expect them to come back in (inaudible) is back on stream, that's number one. Number two, as the volumes go up, we're going to continue to look at different evacuation routes to maximize value, and it will be premature now to say what those numbers are.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the variation, has there been any variation as you've drilled in different areas across the Bakken acreage that you've observed so far, good wells, bad wells?
componenttext: And in terms of the variation, has there been any variation as you've drilled in different areas across the Bakken acreage that you've observed so far, good wells, bad wells?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, on the Bakken, it's a statistical play. So you are going to have variation in your wells. We forecast on a probabilistic basis for the Bakken and we are well within the range. So we're not seeing anything. We're not being surprised by anything. You
componenttext:
So, on the Bakken, it's a statistical play. So you are going to have variation in your wells. We forecast on a probabilistic basis for the Bakken and we are well within the range. So we're not seeing anything. We're not being surprised by anything. 
You had a second question, I think, about Ghana. I haven't seen the well data, and so I really can't comment on what it means.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference call. My name is Madge and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Jay Wilson, Vice
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Hess Corporation First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference call. My name is Madge and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Jay Wilson, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Madge, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears in our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections an
componenttext:
Thank you, Madge, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our first quarter earnings conference call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears in our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements.
With me today are John Hess, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; Greg Hill, President, Worldwide Exploration and Production; and John Rielly, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
I'll now turn the call over to John Hess.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and welcome to our first quarter conference call. I will make a few brief comments, after which John Rielly will review our financial results.Net income for the first quarter of 2010 was $538 million versus a loss of $59 million a year a
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and welcome to our first quarter conference call. I will make a few brief comments, after which John Rielly will review our financial results.
Net income for the first quarter of 2010 was $538 million versus a loss of $59 million a year ago. Our earnings were positively impacted by higher crude oil and natural gas selling prices and production volumes that more than offset the impact of weaker refining results.
Exploration and Production earned $551 million. Crude oil and natural gas production averaged 423,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was 8% above the year ago quarter. This increase resulted primarily from higher production from the Shenzi and Conger Fields in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico and the JDA in the Gulf of Thailand.
In January we closed the previously announced sale of our Jambi Merang asset in Indonesia, receiving proceeds of $183 million. 
At the end of March, we announced the sale of a package of mature, non-operated natural gas production and transportation assets in the U.K. North Sea for $423 million. The sale, which is expected to close in the third quarter, is part of the company's ongoing portfolio management efforts.
We also continue to make progress in finalizing our previously announced strategic asset trade with Shell, which is now expected to close in the second half of this year.  In this trade, Hess will assume Shell's 28.09% interest in the Valhall field and 25% interest in the satellite Hod field in Norway. In return, Shell will assume Hess' 9.29% interest in the Clair Field in the United Kingdom and all of Hess' interest in Gabon.
Although the net effect of these asset sales and the strategic asset trade with Shell is to reduce full year 2010 production by approximately 5,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, our 2010 production forecast remains at 400,000 to 410,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
In North Dakota, net production from the Bakken reached 13,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in March. We currently have five rigs dedicated to drilling Bakken wells and we plan to add five additional rigs over the next 12 months.
With regard to exploration, drilling is continuing on Permits WA-390-P and WA-404-P in the Northwest Shelf of Australia. Also, discussions with potential partners regarding the commercialization of natural gas resources on our 100% owned WA-390-P Block are ongoing. 
In February, we spud the Pony No. 3 well on Green Canyon 469, in which Hess has a 100% working interest. This well, which is still drilling, is designed to test the eastern extent of the Pony structure.  Due to a previous farmout agreement regarding the Stena Forth drillship, we plan to release the rig in early June to another operator and then bring it back to finish drilling the well in the fourth quarter. 
In Brazil, the operator of Block BM-S-22 is in the process of completing the analysis of seismic, log and core data and plans to drill a third well in the second half of 2010.  Hess has a 40% working interest in the block. 
In Indonesia, we have secured a rig to drill the Semai V prospect, in which Hess has 100% working interest. This well is expected to spud by the first quarter of 2011. With regard to our Deepwater Tano Cape Three Points block in Ghana, we are seeking a rig and expect to spud by the first quarter of 2011 as well.
Turning to Marketing and Refining, we reported a profit of $87 million for the first quarter of 2010. Financial results at our HOVENSA joint venture were below the year ago quarter primarily due to costs associated with the planned turnaround of the FCC and higher refinery fuel costs. 
Marketing earnings were better than the first quarter last year. Retail marketing gasoline volumes on a per site basis were down 6%, but total convenience store sales were up 8%, due partly to new product offerings.  In Energy Marketing, although there were fewer heating degree days than the year ago quarter, the business delivered strong financial results. While fuel oil and natural gas sales volume declined year-over-year, electricity sales were higher. 
Solid operating performance and improving commodity prices have strengthened our cash and liquidity position. We remain committed to remaining our financial strength so we are positioned to fund our investment opportunities to profitably grow our reserves and production. 
I will now turn the call over to John Rielly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare first quarter 2010 results for the fourth quarter of 2009. First quarter 2010 consolidated results amounted to net income of $538 million compared with $358 million in the fourth quar
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare first quarter 2010 results for the fourth quarter of 2009. 
First quarter 2010 consolidated results amounted to net income of $538 million compared with $358 million in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Exploration and Production. Exploration and Production operations in the first quarter of 2010 had income of $551 million compared with $494 million in the fourth quarter. The first quarter results included after-tax income of $58 million relating to the sale of the Corporation's interest in the Jambi Merang natural gas development 
project in Indonesia. Excluding the effect of this asset sale, the change in the after-tax components of the results are as follows.  Higher selling prices increased earnings by $48 million. Lower sales volumes decreased earnings by $95 million. Lower costs increased earnings by $48 million. All other items net to a decrease in earnings of $2 million for an overall decrease in first quarter adjusted earnings of $1 million.
Following a large overlift in the fourth quarter of 2009, E&P operations were underlifted compared with production in the first quarter of 2010, which decreased after-tax income by approximately $55 million. The E&P effective income tax rate was 45%.
Turning to Marketing and Refining. Marketing and Refining operations had income of $87 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with income of $17 million in the fourth quarter. 
Refining operations lost $56 million in the first quarter compared with a loss of $40 million in the fourth quarter. The Corporation's share of HOVENSA's results, after income taxes, was a loss of $52 million in the first quarter compared with a loss of $40 million in the fourth quarter.  Port Reading generated a loss of $4 million in the first 
quarter and broke even in the fourth quarter.
During the first quarter, the planned turnaround of the FCC unit at the HOVENSA refinery in St. Croix was completed and operations re-commenced in March 2010. The Corporation's share of HOVENSA's turnaround expenses in the first quarter was approximately $20 million, after income taxes.  In addition, the scheduled turnaround for the Port Reading refining facility commenced in April and is expected to last approximately 35 days. The estimated after-tax expenses to be recorded in the second quarter for the Port Reading 
turnaround are approximately $20 million after tax.
Marketing earnings were $121 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with $45 million in the fourth quarter, principally reflecting seasonally higher margins and refined product volumes in energy marketing operations. Trading activities generated income of $22 million in the first quarter compared with income of $12 million in the fourth quarter.
Turning to Corporate. Net Corporate expenses amounted to $48 million in the first quarter of 2010 compared with $97 million in the fourth quarter. Net Corporate expenses in the first quarter included an after-tax charge of $7 million for the repurchase of the remaining $116 million of bonds that were scheduled to mature in 2011. Net Corporate expenses 
in the fourth quarter included an after-tax charge of $34 million for the repurchase of $546 million of the 2011 bonds and $10 million for pension plan settlements related to employee retirements.  Excluding these special charges, net Corporate expenses were lower in the first quarter, primarily due to lower employee-related costs. 
After-tax interest expense was $52 million in the first quarter compared with $56 million in the fourth quarter.
Turning to cash flow. Net cash provided by operating activities in the first quarter, including a decrease of $432 million from changes in working capital, was $825 million.  Proceeds from the Jambi Merang asset sale were $183 million. Repayments of debt amounted to $142 million. Capital expenditures were $788 million. All other items amounted to a 
decrease in cash of $70 million, resulting in a net increase in cash and cash equivalents in the first quarter of $8 million.
We had $1,370,000,000 of cash and cash equivalents at March 31, 2010, and $1,362,000,000 at December 31, 2009. Our available revolving credit capacity was $3 billion at March 31, 2010.  Total debt was $4,335,000 at March 31, 2010, and $4,467,000 at December 31, 2009. The corporation's debt-to-capitalization ratio at March 31, 2010, was 23.6% compared with 24.8% at the end of 2009.
This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Bakken first, yes, we have five rigs operating. We've got four dual lateral wells that we've completed to date. And while it's still early days, the results are coming in as expected on those wells. So the well cost for those dual-laterals are aver
componenttext:
On the Bakken first, yes, we have five rigs operating. We've got four dual lateral wells that we've completed to date. And while it's still early days, the results are coming in as expected on those wells. So the well cost for those dual-laterals are averaging $10 million to $11 million each. The EUR is about a million barrels per well. And the 30-day 
average IP for those dual-laterals is around 1,000 barrels a day. So that's 450 to 500 barrels per lateral. If I turn to the Marcellus, again we're continuing to build our position in the Marcellus. We are at about 80,000 net acres now in the Marcellus, primarily in Wayne County, Pennsylvania. About 50,000 of that is Hess-operated and the balance is part of this joint venture we have with Newfield. Our plans this year are to drill five to ten wells during the second half of 2010 in order to evaluate the resource potential on the acreage.

componenttext:
Yes, just a little background first on Pony 3. As John said in his opening remarks, it's an appraisal well on our 100% owned Block 469, and it's really designed to delineate the Pony reservoir on the  eastern extension under the block. Now the results of that well are going to be used to determine the final equity split in this combined Pony/Knotty Head 
joint development. I can't give any volume estimates. It's just way too early. I mean, we're only at 25,000 feet in the well.

componenttext: Absolutely. We're both going to use the results of both of those wells to kind of finalize our negotiations on the unitization.

So from that standpoint, there's nothing per say from a deferred tax aspect. So if you remove the working capital, our cash flow would have been above $1.250 
billion in the first quarter.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Mark. Let me just kind of give a broad update about Australia. So we are completing, as we speak, our 12th well. So this will be the 12th of 16 commitment wells. Of those 12, we've had 10 discoveries so far. We plan to finish out drilling tho
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Mark. Let me just kind of give a broad update about Australia. So we are completing, as we speak, our 12th well. So this will be the 12th of 16 commitment wells. Of those 12, we've had 10 discoveries so far. We plan to finish out drilling those 16 commitment wells by mid year. And then after that, we'll follow with an appraisal and flow 
testing phase during the second half. Now as we've said before, we don't plan to give resource estimates until our drilling programs are complete. On the commercialization side, we are continuing again in parallel to work various commercial options with all the potential partners.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, the exploration expenditure in the quarter,  the run rate obviously [indiscernible]  $50 million kind of level, but there's not a whole lot of exploration activity going on. Can you just kind of tell us, what exactly are you doing right now in terms
componenttext:
Greg, the exploration expenditure in the quarter,  the run rate obviously [indiscernible]  $50 million kind of level, but there's not a whole lot of exploration activity going on. Can you just kind of tell us, what exactly are you doing right now in terms of fleshing out the program?  What exactly are you spending on right now? And if you could give 
us an update on the well program for the balance of this year, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico. I think you talked about possibly drilling two unnamed prospects at some point?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The majority of our spend in exploration, as you know, is in Australia. So that's both on our 390 Block and also the 404 Block with Woodside. As we move forward, where is our exploration spend going to move to.  John mentioned in his opening remarks, of c
componenttext: The majority of our spend in exploration, as you know, is in Australia. So that's both on our 390 Block and also the 404 Block with Woodside. As we move forward, where is our exploration spend going to move to.  John mentioned in his opening remarks, of course, Ghana. We're out contracting a rig for Ghana.  We expect to spud the first well early 2011. We've also entered a rig-sharing agreement with Murphy in Indonesia. So we anticipate drilling Semai early 2011, maybe we can squeeze it in in late 2010. And then as we move further into 2011, of course, Australia continues with appraisal and follow up. And then the Stena IV, after she finishes Pony 3, will then begin an exploration program in the Gulf of Mexico. So the plans are she will stay in the Gulf and just continue an exploration program.  So that's a little color on where it's headed.

componenttext: How do you identify the prospects in the Gulf, Greg?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the final one for me is, if we look at the last quarter, you had some issues around the JDA in terms of delivering gas that had been previously paid for. Is that process now complete or can you just give us an update as to where you stand in thos
componenttext: And then the final one for me is, if we look at the last quarter, you had some issues around the JDA in terms of delivering gas that had been previously paid for. Is that process now complete or can you just give us an update as to where you stand in those deliveries?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The take-or-pay, it's not an issue of deliverability from the JDA. It's a take-or-pay contract. So what had happened early in the field due to getting the pipelines online a little bit late, the buyers were required to pay us for gas that wasn't delivered
componenttext: The take-or-pay, it's not an issue of deliverability from the JDA. It's a take-or-pay contract. So what had happened early in the field due to getting the pipelines online a little bit late, the buyers were required to pay us for gas that wasn't delivered. So we recorded a take-or-pay liability, if you want to say "deferred revenues". And what happens is when the buyers take gas above a contractual nomination amount, they eat back into that take-or-pay liability. And it goes back, if you remember in the fourth quarter, what happens is they get it at the prices that were in effect during that time period. So that's why, from a revenue standpoint, we showed a lower realization at the JDA. We still do have about 18 bcf, I think, left in our take-or-pay liability. So we still have deferred revenues up on our books, and that will continue to come down as the buyers take additional gas above the contracted amount.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on your volumes and volume guidance.  I think what you were saying is that there obviously is the issue of the disposals. But I was still surprised given the run rate that you're achieving in this quarter that you would be retaining the full year gui
componenttext:
Just on your volumes and volume guidance.  I think what you were saying is that there obviously is the issue of the disposals. But I was still surprised given the run rate that you're achieving in this quarter that you would be retaining the full year guidance in the previous range. I'm just wondering, first, did I miss something on disposals or other 
reasons why you're doing that? And secondly, if you could add anything else as to how you get to that full year number from what was obviously a strong Q1?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we were happy with our first quarter production performance. And so, I'll come back to the asset trades. I mean, normally for Hess, as you move throughout the year and you get to the second quarter, and particularly in the third quarter, our vo
componenttext:
Obviously, we were happy with our first quarter production performance. And so, I'll come back to the asset trades. I mean, normally for Hess, as you move throughout the year and you get to the second quarter, and particularly in the third quarter, our volumes are always decreased typically due to the shutdowns in the U.K. and normal maintenance that 
is happening across the globe. So we always come in stronger in the first quarter and then dip down. On top of that, we have these asset trades.  So as John has mentioned, the U.K. gas assets, as well is our trade with Shell, are expected to be completed in the second half of the year, which will cause our production to decrease by approximately 5,000 
barrels a day. So at this point here, from our stronger performance, we are not changing our guidance that we went out earlier in the year with. So we are reflecting some of that stronger performance, but we are keeping our guidance at 400 to 410.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.  But I guess it's a conservative number, isn't it?
componenttext: Yes.  But I guess it's a conservative number, isn't it?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I mean again, we'll continue to update everyone as we go throughout the year. But we feel comfortable with that forecast range.
componenttext: No. I mean again, we'll continue to update everyone as we go throughout the year. But we feel comfortable with that forecast range.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could continue on the guidance a little bit, please.  I think you mentioned $1.250 as your underlying cash flow from operations? Was there anything one-off about that number? I'm thinking about tax rates or anything else that might have boosted t
componenttext: And if I could continue on the guidance a little bit, please.  I think you mentioned $1.250 as your underlying cash flow from operations? Was there anything one-off about that number? I'm thinking about tax rates or anything else that might have boosted that. And the extension is that we heard about under $80 barrel of oil here and you're well in excess in terms of cash flows above CapEx and dividends. Could you just address how you intend to utilize that excess cash over the course of the year? My guidance is the CapEx number is $4.1 billion. Anything you can add on dividend policy of that paydown will be great?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let me start with your first question, were there one-offs in the quarter.  So cash flow from operating activities, and I'm excluding working capital, it was as you said $1.250 billion. There we're no real one-offs in there. You were asking about the t
componenttext:
So let me start with your first question, were there one-offs in the quarter.  So cash flow from operating activities, and I'm excluding working capital, it was as you said $1.250 billion. There we're no real one-offs in there. You were asking about the tax rate, and if you're looking at our press release just from the E&P earnings, which includes the special, you'll see a tax rate around 40% for the group.  However, that includes a special item on the Jambi Merang sale, and that sale, due to that it was a share sale, did not have tax associated with it. So our run rate for the first quarter, excluding the special, was 45%. A little below our guidance, but basically really no one-offs in the first quarter from a cash flow standpoint. As you're going forward through the year, it's early in the year right now, so we have that guidance at $4.1 billion. You'll always have things that move in, move out of our CapEx profile. At this point, we will update. It is our plan to update on the second quarter conference call on where our CapEx is 
going.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.  And I guess what I was driving at is that you're generating excess cash. Would you be pushing CapEx up?  Would you be pushing dividend up? Would you be pushing debt down, as a general?
componenttext: Okay.  And I guess what I was driving at is that you're generating excess cash. Would you be pushing CapEx up?  Would you be pushing dividend up? Would you be pushing debt down, as a general?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, Paul, the priority for our cash flow is to grow our reserves and production profitably. Our CapEx program reflects that.  At the middle of the year, we'll be giving an update on that CapEx program. And it's a little hard now and inappropriate
componenttext:
As you know, Paul, the priority for our cash flow is to grow our reserves and production profitably. Our CapEx program reflects that.  At the middle of the year, we'll be giving an update on that CapEx program. And it's a little hard now and inappropriate now to get ahead of ourselves. So the first call on cash is CapEx and then maintaining the 
company's financial strength for future investments.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Neil McMahon from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Back again to Australia, obviously you're looking at the best ways to commercialize the acreage there. Have you done any thinking as to whether it could be an outright exit out of Australia having done extremely well in the exploration program, or are you
componenttext:
Back again to Australia, obviously you're looking at the best ways to commercialize the acreage there. Have you done any thinking as to whether it could be an outright exit out of Australia having done extremely well in the exploration program, or are you looking at trying to get some sort of partnership in the LNG schemes that are going on, 
particularly with Woodside? if you could give us any color on that? And secondly, just really any update on Libya and offshore. Have you had any interest from any of the bigger companies in terms of farming into your discovery there? Or any updates in terms of how your geological, geophysical studies are going?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, let me address Australia. Our intention is to commercialize those resources. So that is our primary intention. As I've said earlier, we're working with three different parties down there. We've made no decisions on what liquefaction
componenttext:
I think, first of all, let me address Australia. Our intention is to commercialize those resources. So that is our primary intention. As I've said earlier, we're working with three different parties down there. We've made no decisions on what liquefaction route we're going to take because we are still in  commercial discussions and we want to make 
sure we understand all the resources on the block before we make any decisions. In regards to Libya, recall we had two successful flow tests on the Libyan Block and right now we are currently on a joint feasibility study with the NOC, which concludes development plans and commercial terms. So that's kind of where we are on Libya right now.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And any interest from other players in getting involved with you in Libya?
componenttext: And any interest from other players in getting involved with you in Libya?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've had companies approach us. We've made no decisions on involving others in Libya at this point.
componenttext: We've had companies approach us. We've made no decisions on involving others in Libya at this point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line from Robert Kessler from Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line from Robert Kessler from Simmons & Company.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, I might be getting too granular on the Bakken rate of change over just three months, but I wanted to get a view points of clarification there. It looks like you're about 13,000 barrels a day now on the Bakken versus about 10,000 barrels a day about
componenttext: Greg, I might be getting too granular on the Bakken rate of change over just three months, but I wanted to get a view points of clarification there. It looks like you're about 13,000 barrels a day now on the Bakken versus about 10,000 barrels a day about three months ago, which seems like a pretty good clip of growth given, I think, your full-year guidance for about 4,000 to 5,000 barrels a day of growth in the Bakken. Is it outperforming your expectations, and as a result is there some upside to that full-year expectation?  And then just kind of looking at your quotes on the four dual-laterals completed to date, all that's about the same number you had in January. And with five rigs running and I thought the bulk of the development activity dedicated to the dual lateral completion technique now, just wondering if maybe you've got a few wells now queued up awaiting completion that have been drilled, or again, maybe I'm splitting hairs. But just any more color trying to help me fit those pieces together, if you don't mind.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the production rate first, we are essentially on plan and we're sticking with our 20,000 barrel-a-day production rate at exit rate for the year. So no change there.  Regarding your questions about the wells, I think probably what I said on the last
componenttext:
So on the production rate first, we are essentially on plan and we're sticking with our 20,000 barrel-a-day production rate at exit rate for the year. So no change there.  Regarding your questions about the wells, I think probably what I said on the last call is that we drilled four wells. We've actually drilled nine dual-laterals now. We just 
have completed four. So they're in various phases of completion.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe a broader question on the Bakken and following up on  some of your previous comments on the dual-laterals on whether you envision any change in the type of wells that you'll be drilling as you ramp activity. Maybe for a lack of a better term, reserv
componenttext:
Maybe a broader question on the Bakken and following up on  some of your previous comments on the dual-laterals on whether you envision any change in the type of wells that you'll be drilling as you ramp activity. Maybe for a lack of a better term, reservoir characterization mode to a manufacturing mode, meaning is there going to be change from 
dual lateral to a single lateral. And then secondly, and somewhat related, I know in your last call, you referenced long-term Bakken service contracts as more imminent. Has anything been awarded there, any cost advantage of a lockup?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So where are we on the drilling? So our current base plan is to utilize the dual lateral across most of our Phase I acreage. And that's because the middle Bakken and Three Forks are largely present across that Phase I acreage. Now the cost advantage is if
componenttext:
So where are we on the drilling? So our current base plan is to utilize the dual lateral across most of our Phase I acreage. And that's because the middle Bakken and Three Forks are largely present across that Phase I acreage. Now the cost advantage is if approach is clear. You get one left vertical wellbore.  You have fewer down hole equipment.  You 
have fewer surface facilities.  So we really believe that this dual lateral approach, combined with the application [indiscernible] manufacturing techniques and pad drilling, is going to result in superior returns for us on the Bakken, which is why we're going with that approach. Now I will say its early days.  As we learn, as we need to, we'll change 
and modify as appropriate.   But right now we're happy with the dual lateral performance.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And any update on the long-term service contracts?
componenttext: And any update on the long-term service contracts?

componenttext: Yes. We've awarded the drilling rate contracts for the five-year terms.  We've awarded the pumping services contracts for five-year terms. And we've  awarded various construction contracts with kind of varying terms, length of terms.

componenttext: The recent Brunei/Malaysia offshore territorial dispute being settled and opening up exploration there.  I know Total is the operator and has the 15% interest. Any idea or kind of thoughts on timing  there in what's a pretty interesting neighborhood?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're encouraged that the governments are talking and really seem intent on settling this issue finally.  There's a partner meeting at the end of the month with the operator at the end of next month  to talk about the go-forward plan.  So th
componenttext: Well, I think we're encouraged that the governments are talking and really seem intent on settling this issue finally.  There's a partner meeting at the end of the month with the operator at the end of next month  to talk about the go-forward plan.  So that's really all I can say at this point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on Ghana. Obviously, a small dry hole for [indiscernible].  I mean, does that change anything in terms of your view of your acreage there?  And a follow-up on the Bakken in terms of have there been any kind of variation in the well results in ear
componenttext: Question on Ghana. Obviously, a small dry hole for [indiscernible].  I mean, does that change anything in terms of your view of your acreage there?  And a follow-up on the Bakken in terms of have there been any kind of variation in the well results in early days from region to region? And perhaps some commentary on the discounts that you think you'll get from the Bakken relative to WTI, really driven by the ability to get the crude oil out of the region?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. The discounts I'll go with first and then Greg will pick up on the other questions  you asked.  Currently, the discounts have widened a little by about $2 off the WTI, so it's about $4 going to $6  range, about. And that's because of the Mandan [ph]
componenttext:
Yes. The discounts I'll go with first and then Greg will pick up on the other questions  you asked.  Currently, the discounts have widened a little by about $2 off the WTI, so it's about $4 going to $6  range, about. And that's because of the Mandan [ph] turnaround and work that's going on there. We can't predict differentials, what WTI is going to do, 
but we see that narrowing back. So the pricing that we've gotten in the past, for at least the next year going forward, we think that will hold for the increase in our Bakken.  So anywhere from $2 to $6, let's call it a $4 average.  That's a guesstimate at best. But I'm just trying to give you a feel that while the discounts have widened out in the 
last month or so, we expect them to come back once Mandan [ph] is back on stream. That's number one.  Number two, as the volumes go up, we're going to continue to look at different evacuation routes to maximum value and it would be premature now to say what those numbers are.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
