componenttextpreview: I guess the overlift will be a big contributor to them. I actually have two questions, one is on the Eagle Ford. Effectively, can you talk through your strategy there? And I think on Q2, you spoke of further acquisitions in other non-conventional. So perh
componenttext: I guess the overlift will be a big contributor to them. I actually have two questions, one is on the Eagle Ford. Effectively, can you talk through your strategy there? And I think on Q2, you spoke of further acquisitions in other non-conventional. So perhaps a broader comment on the non-conventional strategy. And then the second one is around Refining. I mean, you're still obviously losing net income, perhaps some decisions around profit improvements or any plans on disposal.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ed, this is Greg Hill. Let me talk about the Eagle Ford, and then I'll talk about a little bit broader about unconventional strategy. So yes, we are building and have been building a position in the Eagle Ford. We have about 75,000 net acres, as we s
componenttext: Yes, Ed, this is Greg Hill. Let me talk about the Eagle Ford, and then I'll talk about a little bit broader about unconventional strategy. So yes, we are building and have been building a position in the Eagle Ford. We have about 75,000 net acres, as we speak, under a contract. And our plans are to begin drilling in November in the Eagle Ford. And if we can get additional acreage, we'll expand that position further. Regarding kind of broader unconventionals, as we've said before, we're really focused domestically in the U.S. in our Bakken position and the Eagle Ford, and we have our position in the Marcellus. We continue to look for other opportunities, but we're also focused internationally. And of course, we have our Paris Basin position of about 1 million acres or so with our partner, Toreador. And we've signed a memorandum of understanding and an agreement with PetroChina to look at unconventional possibilities in Daqing Field in China.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of Refining, specifically HOVENSA, we're disappointed with the operating performance of the facility, as well as the financial performance, and we are working with our partners to find ways to improve both.
componenttext: In terms of Refining, specifically HOVENSA, we're disappointed with the operating performance of the facility, as well as the financial performance, and we are working with our partners to find ways to improve both.

componenttext: I guess if we could talk a bit more about the Bakken, please. Could you just update us? At a high level, firstly, I guess, there's an implicit increase to your production target there once you've completed the American Oil & Gas, certainly. And I wondered if there may be also upward pressure from the kind of performance you're getting out of your activities there? If you could kind of address the high-level question, also talk more about all the technical things that you're doing and the progress that you are making there, that would be kind.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Greg. Well, first of all, let me say we're on track in the Bakken. We continue to make significant progress. We're on track to exit the year at a net production rate of about 20,000 barrels a day. As we said, we're marching our way towards 8
componenttext: Paul, this is Greg. Well, first of all, let me say we're on track in the Bakken. We continue to make significant progress. We're on track to exit the year at a net production rate of about 20,000 barrels a day. As we said, we're marching our way towards 80,000 barrels a day in our existing position in the Bakken. Regarding the American Oil & Gas position, of course, we have not yet acquired that. We're optimistic that, that will close, but it's early days. We'd like to get a few wells in the ground before we issue any additional production guidance associated with that. But obviously, we're excited about the acreage, otherwise, we wouldn't have acquired it. Just briefly, well costs are coming in at about $11 million each for dual lateral. EUR is about 1 million barrels per dual and our 30-day average IP rates are on the order of 400 to 500 barrels per day per lateral from 18-stage fracs. So that gives you kind of an overall update on the Bakken.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The West Med writedown, I was a bit surprised by that. Could you just explain what that was about?
componenttext: The West Med writedown, I was a bit surprised by that. Could you just explain what that was about?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, while we did have several natural gas discoveries on the block, based on the technical work and working with our partners, the quantities of gas found are not sufficient to pursue their commercial development at this time. So during the quar
componenttext: Sure. I mean, while we did have several natural gas discoveries on the block, based on the technical work and working with our partners, the quantities of gas found are not sufficient to pursue their commercial development at this time. So during the quarter, actually, late in the quarter, the partners decided to cease future exploration activities on the block, again, just from the risks of some of the plays and the ability to make it commercial. And they actually now have decided to relinquish a significant portion of the block. So as a result of that decision by the partnership group, just following the GAAP accounting standards, we had to take an impairment in this quarter.

componenttext: Yes, so in the Northern Red Sea, this is Block 1, where we have an 80% working interest and we're the operator. It's a Cretaceous sandstone play. It's in about 710 meters of water. It's going to take about 90 days to drill and it's an oil prospect that we're looking for oil.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Going to the Exploration program, 100% in Ghana, 100% Semai, 80% in Egypt and a whole bunch of gas in Australia that doesn't have a home yet. Can you just talk about strategically how you might think about perhaps cross-border asset swaps and perhaps, in
componenttext: Going to the Exploration program, 100% in Ghana, 100% Semai, 80% in Egypt and a whole bunch of gas in Australia that doesn't have a home yet. Can you just talk about strategically how you might think about perhaps cross-border asset swaps and perhaps, in light of your recent commentary that you may not drill some of these wells with such high interest in the future? That's my first, and I have a follow-up, please.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think our strategy is to acquire opportunities at high-working interest. And then as we derisk the wells, then we make a separate decision on whether or not we're going to farm them down or not. I think in Ghana and Semai, we're in active discussions wi
componenttext: I think our strategy is to acquire opportunities at high-working interest. And then as we derisk the wells, then we make a separate decision on whether or not we're going to farm them down or not. I think in Ghana and Semai, we're in active discussions with a number of potential partners for farming offers. And I think assuming, we get an acceptable deal, we'll probably farm down both of those wells, predrill. You had mentioned Australia as well. I mean, obviously, we're not going to build LNG plants in Australia. So we will likely take a partner on our 100% position in Australia as well, linked to the liquefaction route.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, should we expect that the farm down of Ghana, given that it's going to spud here pretty quickly, might be related in some way to accelerating your plays in the Q for LNG in Australia? Are the two linked? Or is it completely separate in terms of your
componenttext: Greg, should we expect that the farm down of Ghana, given that it's going to spud here pretty quickly, might be related in some way to accelerating your plays in the Q for LNG in Australia? Are the two linked? Or is it completely separate in terms of your partner negotiations?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say they're necessarily linked, Doug. I mean, some of the partners we are talking to have positions in Australia. And so we're talking to them about a number of potential cross-border deals or just a straight promote.
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say they're necessarily linked, Doug. I mean, some of the partners we are talking to have positions in Australia. And so we're talking to them about a number of potential cross-border deals or just a straight promote.

componenttext: Would the same apply to Egypt? Would you expect to farm that down as well? Or would you believe that you'd drill 80%?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: Just jumping back to the Eagle Ford, can you tell us where exactly your acreages in terms of counties, oil-gas windows, that kind of stuff? And basically, what is your plan for the rig count? You gave us a pretty clear signal as what you were going to do in the Bakken. But on the Eagle Ford, what is your drilling plan and potential ramp-up there that we should expect over the next year?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's early days in the Eagle Ford. I guess what I will say is we're firmly in the condensate window. And our plan is to drill six wells starting in November, just to begin assessing the acreage. After that, then we'll make a decision on how to expand and
componenttext: It's early days in the Eagle Ford. I guess what I will say is we're firmly in the condensate window. And our plan is to drill six wells starting in November, just to begin assessing the acreage. After that, then we'll make a decision on how to expand and ramp up after we get those initial six wells drilled.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the last one for me, this one's maybe for Mr. Hess. The Bakken on the Valhall deals appear to give you a pretty good anchor on your 3% growth targets. But that doesn't include, obviously, the incremental interest in Tubular Bells, the potential Pony d
componenttext: And the last one for me, this one's maybe for Mr. Hess. The Bakken on the Valhall deals appear to give you a pretty good anchor on your 3% growth targets. But that doesn't include, obviously, the incremental interest in Tubular Bells, the potential Pony development. Can you speak to how you're thinking about your production guidance or longer-term targets now that those deals have been done?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good question, Doug. And basically, our investment program in the Bakken and now having captured a larger interest in Valhall, that also has incremental production over the next five years, we feel pretty good that both of those assets will underpin a min
componenttext: Good question, Doug. And basically, our investment program in the Bakken and now having captured a larger interest in Valhall, that also has incremental production over the next five years, we feel pretty good that both of those assets will underpin a minimum of 3% production growth in oil equipment over the next five years. So that's the way you think about our production guidance, but that really is a minimum. And then as you rightfully point out, as the Gulf of Mexico regulatory environment gets clarified, hopefully, we'll be able to sanction both the Pony and Tubular Bells developments that would be incremental to our picture, as well as hopefully, some success, either in other unconventionals that Greg is talking about or some of the exploratory prospects that we have longer-term. So we feel we acquired a lot of attractive growth options, some of them will not be successful, but hopefully, some will. And that would be incremental to that minimum 3% production growth guidance.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: But that also applied to the American Oil & Gas, is that also additive?
componenttext: But that also applied to the American Oil & Gas, is that also additive?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the best way to look at American Oil & Gas that, that's incremental, but on the margin. So it's definitely supportive of that minimum 3% growth guidance.
componenttext: I think the best way to look at American Oil & Gas that, that's incremental, but on the margin. So it's definitely supportive of that minimum 3% growth guidance.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Gilman from Benchmark Co.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Gilman from Benchmark Co.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, with respect to the parameters on Bakken that you outlined before, give me an idea, if you would, whether that represents an average to date? And what it looks like from a trend or most current standpoint?
componenttext: Greg, with respect to the parameters on Bakken that you outlined before, give me an idea, if you would, whether that represents an average to date? And what it looks like from a trend or most current standpoint?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, on those well results that I quoted, that's an average to date based on the results that we've seen. And I think the only change that we're seeing in the short-term is we're going to 22-stage fracs, that's a current design. The averages I quoted
componenttext: I think, on those well results that I quoted, that's an average to date based on the results that we've seen. And I think the only change that we're seeing in the short-term is we're going to 22-stage fracs, that's a current design. The averages I quoted in Tubular is based on 18-stage fracs. So there will be a little uplift in those as we go into 22-stage.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, while I have you, perhaps you could help me to understand the Tubular Bells transaction. I guess I don't quite understand the nominal consideration. I don't quite understand BP divesting a small portion of it but retaining an interest. A little bit
componenttext: Greg, while I have you, perhaps you could help me to understand the Tubular Bells transaction. I guess I don't quite understand the nominal consideration. I don't quite understand BP divesting a small portion of it but retaining an interest. A little bit hard for me to relate to exactly what's going on there and what your expectations are. Some comment would be appreciated.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think in terms of Tubular Bells, obviously, BP is restructuring their business globally post-Macondo. And so this presented us with an opportunity to increase our interest and become operator of the asset. So we like Tubular Bells. Our partner likes Tub
componenttext: I think in terms of Tubular Bells, obviously, BP is restructuring their business globally post-Macondo. And so this presented us with an opportunity to increase our interest and become operator of the asset. So we like Tubular Bells. Our partner likes Tubular Bells. Obviously, BP likes Tubular Bells because they wanted to retain an interest in it. I wouldn't say anything more than that. It's just them restructuring in their portfolio.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The development history there, Greg, has been -- or the appraisal history, I guess I should say, has been a bit mixed. Has there been a downgrade in your mind in terms of the resource potential?
componenttext: The development history there, Greg, has been -- or the appraisal history, I guess I should say, has been a bit mixed. Has there been a downgrade in your mind in terms of the resource potential?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we've said about Tubular Bells before is we see it in excess of 100 million barrels. And we'll provide some additional information post-sanction on the volume side.
componenttext: I think what we've said about Tubular Bells before is we see it in excess of 100 million barrels. And we'll provide some additional information post-sanction on the volume side.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a gross number, I assume?
componenttext: That's a gross number, I assume?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, gross.
componenttext: Yes, gross.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding European gas, give me an idea, if you could, in rough terms, how much you sell spot versus how much is under contract? And also, any portion that may be specifically linked in one way, shape or form to crude oil and/or petroleum product prices?
componenttext: Regarding European gas, give me an idea, if you could, in rough terms, how much you sell spot versus how much is under contract? And also, any portion that may be specifically linked in one way, shape or form to crude oil and/or petroleum product prices?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So basically, you've got a mix, when you're looking at Europe, between U.K., Norway and Denmark. Pretty much, the majority of our production is coming out of the U.K., and that is being sold at spot prices. In Norway and Denmark, there you have contractua
componenttext: So basically, you've got a mix, when you're looking at Europe, between U.K., Norway and Denmark. Pretty much, the majority of our production is coming out of the U.K., and that is being sold at spot prices. In Norway and Denmark, there you have contractual terms to it that does have some linkage then to the oil markets.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exciting exploration calendar in the 2011, I guess, I have two follow-up questions. One for Greg on the Red Sea. I mean, any predrill range there or a description more of what the play type is? And if you guys are doing a two-well program, are those back-
componenttext: Exciting exploration calendar in the 2011, I guess, I have two follow-up questions. One for Greg on the Red Sea. I mean, any predrill range there or a description more of what the play type is? And if you guys are doing a two-well program, are those back-to-back wells that you're thinking right now?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, Evan, the Northern Red Sea block is a Cretaceous sandstone play, that's the first well. We believe it's an oil, it will be an oil prospect. And the prospect size is on the order of 100 million to 200 million barrels. The second well is a bit depend
componenttext: Again, Evan, the Northern Red Sea block is a Cretaceous sandstone play, that's the first well. We believe it's an oil, it will be an oil prospect. And the prospect size is on the order of 100 million to 200 million barrels. The second well is a bit dependent on the first well. We do plan to drill a second well, but the location of that well really depends on what happens with the first well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it's the same play type then?
componenttext: So it's the same play type then?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, it depends on the results of the first well.
componenttext: Again, it depends on the results of the first well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-up, if I could also, on a prior question on the farm down. I mean, just a general understanding, I fully appreciate you're assessing all the opportunities. But I mean, is the assessor's goal in a potential swap to remain exploration neut
componenttext: And then a follow-up, if I could also, on a prior question on the farm down. I mean, just a general understanding, I fully appreciate you're assessing all the opportunities. But I mean, is the assessor's goal in a potential swap to remain exploration neutral, if you would, meaning to swap interest in other projects? Or is that incorrect to think about that way?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think that you shouldn't assume that as a general rule. It depends on the well. It depends on the technical and the commercial risk profile of the well. Sometimes we'll take cash in the form of a promote and/or an international swap. It just really
componenttext: No, I think that you shouldn't assume that as a general rule. It depends on the well. It depends on the technical and the commercial risk profile of the well. Sometimes we'll take cash in the form of a promote and/or an international swap. It just really depends well by well.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Arjun Murti from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Arjun Murti from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Australia commercial timing, can we think about that as first half of '11 or is there -- do you want to do some of the appraisal work first?
componenttext: On the Australia commercial timing, can we think about that as first half of '11 or is there -- do you want to do some of the appraisal work first?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we want to do is we want to do the appraisal work. We need to get some critical well data during the appraisal phase that's key for long-term development planning and pipeline design and those kind of things. As we've said before, in parallel
componenttext: I think what we want to do is we want to do the appraisal work. We need to get some critical well data during the appraisal phase that's key for long-term development planning and pipeline design and those kind of things. As we've said before, in parallel, we're actually working the commercial side, the liquefaction route. But hopefully, by the middle of 2011, we'll be in a position to pick a route. We'll have a significant part of our appraisal program done and then can make an informed decision around the sanction.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the options there are still floating LNG, with Shell, Woodside Pluto-2 and, I think, Wheatstone are the three possibilities for you?
componenttext: And the options there are still floating LNG, with Shell, Woodside Pluto-2 and, I think, Wheatstone are the three possibilities for you?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, with the other possibility of Northwest Shelf, and all as it becomes available sometime in the future.
componenttext: Yes, with the other possibility of Northwest Shelf, and all as it becomes available sometime in the future.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned in the prepared remarks, it might have been John Hess, the PetroChina memorandum of understanding. Can you just elaborate on what that opportunity is at Daqing in terms of pursuing, presumably Shell Oil opportunities there?
componenttext: You mentioned in the prepared remarks, it might have been John Hess, the PetroChina memorandum of understanding. Can you just elaborate on what that opportunity is at Daqing in terms of pursuing, presumably Shell Oil opportunities there?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we've signed a joint study agreement with PetroChina. And basically, it's a tight oil zone in the Daqing Field, that potentially by applying Bakken-like technology, you can unlock. So that's currently what we're looking at.
componenttext: Yes, so we've signed a joint study agreement with PetroChina. And basically, it's a tight oil zone in the Daqing Field, that potentially by applying Bakken-like technology, you can unlock. So that's currently what we're looking at.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And presumably, the memorandum of understanding is for specifically that zone, as opposed to an overall interest in the field or anything greater than that?
componenttext: And presumably, the memorandum of understanding is for specifically that zone, as opposed to an overall interest in the field or anything greater than that?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is. It's specific to the tight oil zone in the Daqing Field.
componenttext: Yes, it is. It's specific to the tight oil zone in the Daqing Field.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a final question in terms of what you think is a realistic timing to getting back to exploration in the Gulf of Mexico, given the lifting of the moratorium, but obviously, there are permitting questions and so forth?
componenttext: As a final question in terms of what you think is a realistic timing to getting back to exploration in the Gulf of Mexico, given the lifting of the moratorium, but obviously, there are permitting questions and so forth?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: A good question, Arjun. I think everyone in the industry is asking that. As you know, there's still a lot of uncertainty, both regulatory and legislatively, as to what's coming at us. So even though the moratorium has been lifted, we're still kind of mid-
componenttext: A good question, Arjun. I think everyone in the industry is asking that. As you know, there's still a lot of uncertainty, both regulatory and legislatively, as to what's coming at us. So even though the moratorium has been lifted, we're still kind of mid-cycle, I guess, in terms of regulatory and legislative understanding of what's going to happen. I think for planning purposes, we're hoping to get back to work in the Gulf of Mexico in the middle of 2011 sometime, but that's just a planning assumption at this point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Cheng from Barclays Capital.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: A number of quick questions, hopefully. Greg, based on what you say presumably that the Pony appraisal well is not going to be drilled in December? And in terms of the process after unitization with Knotty Head, do you guys have to wait until you finish t
componenttext: A number of quick questions, hopefully. Greg, based on what you say presumably that the Pony appraisal well is not going to be drilled in December? And in terms of the process after unitization with Knotty Head, do you guys have to wait until you finish the last appraisal well and they finished there? Or that you can still go ahead and try to unitize and maybe have a pause that after the last appraisal well make an adjustment. How does that process work?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me give you a quick update, Paul, on just where we are. So we continue to make significant progress towards sanction of Pony. So we've just signed a letter of agreement, a confidentiality agreement and a data trade agreement with the Knotty Head
componenttext: Yes, let me give you a quick update, Paul, on just where we are. So we continue to make significant progress towards sanction of Pony. So we've just signed a letter of agreement, a confidentiality agreement and a data trade agreement with the Knotty Head partners. So the next step now is negotiate the JOA, which should be completed early next year. Obviously, the timing of the sanction is uncertain due to the permitting delays. But specifically to the Pony 3 well, we intend to get back to Pony 3 as soon as we can obtain a permit from the BOEM [Bureau of Ocean Energy Management], and we're in the process of filing all that paperwork as we speak. And so really, for just for planning assumptions, we're assuming that we can get back to Pony 3 sometime in the second half of 2011. Now that doesn't mean we're still not pursuing, doing all the design work, the feed work, progressing the JOA with the partners, all those things to move Pony forward.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in other words, we should not assume that just because you couldn't drill on the last appraisal well that you are in a holding pattern. You're still moving forward, and there is a possibility that you may be able to finalize and done much of that even
componenttext: So in other words, we should not assume that just because you couldn't drill on the last appraisal well that you are in a holding pattern. You're still moving forward, and there is a possibility that you may be able to finalize and done much of that even before the last appraisal well?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We're moving forward, so all that stuff happens in parallel.
componenttext: Absolutely. We're moving forward, so all that stuff happens in parallel.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And normally that you guys don't give any guidance on the next year production and CapEx until after you report the fourth quarter. Is there any kind of rough direction that you can give us in terms of up, down, flat?
componenttext: And normally that you guys don't give any guidance on the next year production and CapEx until after you report the fourth quarter. Is there any kind of rough direction that you can give us in terms of up, down, flat?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Paul, I think you said it, we're still in the process of going through all that now and looking at the program for next year, and so we will update the guidance in our January call.
componenttext: No, Paul, I think you said it, we're still in the process of going through all that now and looking at the program for next year, and so we will update the guidance in our January call.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And for 2010 Production, given the strong results in the third quarter, should we assume it's going to be closer to the high end of the range instead of the middle of the range?
componenttext: And for 2010 Production, given the strong results in the third quarter, should we assume it's going to be closer to the high end of the range instead of the middle of the range?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, given the results to date, and actually a somewhat later than expected timing of the closing of our U.K. North Sea natural gas asset sale, we will be at the upper end of our range.
componenttext: Yes, given the results to date, and actually a somewhat later than expected timing of the closing of our U.K. North Sea natural gas asset sale, we will be at the upper end of our range.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, after you complete the acquisition of the American Oil & Gas, in theory, you had 13 rigs. Are you guys going to stick to the 13 rig? Or are you just scaling back down to the 10 rig and just stick with that $1 billion a year kind of capital spending
componenttext: Greg, after you complete the acquisition of the American Oil & Gas, in theory, you had 13 rigs. Are you guys going to stick to the 13 rig? Or are you just scaling back down to the 10 rig and just stick with that $1 billion a year kind of capital spending program?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Paul. The American Oil & Gas will be incremental. We plan to develop that with a three-rig program, so we'll be up to a 13-rig program. So we won't dial back to 10.
componenttext: No, Paul. The American Oil & Gas will be incremental. We plan to develop that with a three-rig program, so we'll be up to a 13-rig program. So we won't dial back to 10.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: In quantity, I know that it's a little bit premature. Can we somewhat -- using a prorated, that if you're looking for adding about 15,000 barrel per day using a 10-rig program a year, when you use a 13, can we prorated that, it would be closer to 20,000 b
componenttext: In quantity, I know that it's a little bit premature. Can we somewhat -- using a prorated, that if you're looking for adding about 15,000 barrel per day using a 10-rig program a year, when you use a 13, can we prorated that, it would be closer to 20,000 barrel per day increase? In other words, that the quality of the American Oil & Gas, should we assume that it would be somewhat similar to the area that you're working on today?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think, Paul, it's real early to figure out what American Oil & Gas is going to provide or whether you can scale it or whatever. So let's get a few wells down and then we'll provide a formal update on what that's going to deliver for us.
componenttext: Yes, so I think, Paul, it's real early to figure out what American Oil & Gas is going to provide or whether you can scale it or whatever. So let's get a few wells down and then we'll provide a formal update on what that's going to deliver for us.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: A final question on Bakken. With the Alberta prepare and the Keystone is up and running, it seems like we have more pipeline capacity than the Canadian heavy oil that is currently available. Is there any opportunity for you guys to ship in order to utiliz
componenttext: A final question on Bakken. With the Alberta prepare and the Keystone is up and running, it seems like we have more pipeline capacity than the Canadian heavy oil that is currently available. Is there any opportunity for you guys to ship in order to utilize those pipe for Bakken so that narrows the Bakken discount?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, a couple of dimensions there. First, we have our traditional marketing agreements: number one, with pipelines in the area; number two, we're putting in a rail facility, which will give us a lot of flex; and number three, we're working with Enbridge
componenttext: Paul, a couple of dimensions there. First, we have our traditional marketing agreements: number one, with pipelines in the area; number two, we're putting in a rail facility, which will give us a lot of flex; and number three, we're working with Enbridge on this new pipeline expansion that they have. So those are the sort of the three options that we're doing that should be able to accommodate the production growth that we envision over the next five, six years.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the Paris Basin. Originally I was thinking that the testing will begin in the fourth quarter. It sounds like you mentioned the first quarter of '11 you would begin drilling. Any sense of when we might have kind of final determination o
componenttext: I had a question on the Paris Basin. Originally I was thinking that the testing will begin in the fourth quarter. It sounds like you mentioned the first quarter of '11 you would begin drilling. Any sense of when we might have kind of final determination on whether that play is going to be economical or not?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what we can say at this point is that sometime in 2011 because we'll start drilling our first wells in early 2011. And we'll have certainly have some indication of the commerciality of the play in 2011.
componenttext: Yes, I think what we can say at this point is that sometime in 2011 because we'll start drilling our first wells in early 2011. And we'll have certainly have some indication of the commerciality of the play in 2011.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Back to the Bakken. I know there's been some discussion whether the dual completions are the way to go or not. It sounds, Greg, to me like you're still comfortable with that and confident that, that's the way that Hess is going to continue to pursue the p
componenttext: Back to the Bakken. I know there's been some discussion whether the dual completions are the way to go or not. It sounds, Greg, to me like you're still comfortable with that and confident that, that's the way that Hess is going to continue to pursue the play, right?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are.
componenttext: Yes, we are.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the final one for me is on the cost in the Eagle Ford. I'm just curious if you're providing any  cost on what you're paying per acre out there?
componenttext: And then the final one for me is on the cost in the Eagle Ford. I'm just curious if you're providing any  cost on what you're paying per acre out there?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we're not. Obviously, that's fairly competitively sensitive.
componenttext: No, we're not. Obviously, that's fairly competitively sensitive.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Pavel Molchanov from Raymond James.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, on predrill reserve estimates. I appreciate you sharing that for the Red Sea. I wanted to see if I can get you to give those numbers also for the next BM-S-22 prospect and/or for Ghana?
componenttext: First, on predrill reserve estimates. I appreciate you sharing that for the Red Sea. I wanted to see if I can get you to give those numbers also for the next BM-S-22 prospect and/or for Ghana?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we typically don't do that. So no, I'm not going to give you those estimates.
componenttext: No, we typically don't do that. So no, I'm not going to give you those estimates.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then another follow-on on the Paris Basin. If you move to full-scale development down the road, are there any infrastructure or kind of offtake capacity issues that would potentially slow you down? I guess I'm trying to get a sense of when production
componenttext: And then another follow-on on the Paris Basin. If you move to full-scale development down the road, are there any infrastructure or kind of offtake capacity issues that would potentially slow you down? I guess I'm trying to get a sense of when production there could begin to move the needle for you guys?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think on the Paris Basin, it's still early days. We've got to drill our first wells to even see if there is a commercial development there. There is existing capacity in the basin. There's a refinery nearby. And so obviously, before we entered the play,
componenttext: I think on the Paris Basin, it's still early days. We've got to drill our first wells to even see if there is a commercial development there. There is existing capacity in the basin. There's a refinery nearby. And so obviously, before we entered the play, we looked at those things and don't see them as a significant constraint at this point.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is a follow-up question from the line of Mark Gilman from Benchmark.
componenttext: Your next question is a follow-up question from the line of Mark Gilman from Benchmark.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, I wonder, could you provide some volume number to that overlift and give me a rough idea where?
componenttext: John, I wonder, could you provide some volume number to that overlift and give me a rough idea where?

componenttextpreview: Sure, Mark. It was a 2.1 million barrel overlift in the quarter. It was primarily EG, it's about 1.1 million barrels, and then the U.K. and Gabon, both at around 500,000.
componenttext: Sure, Mark. It was a 2.1 million barrel overlift in the quarter. It was primarily EG, it's about 1.1 million barrels, and then the U.K. and Gabon, both at around 500,000.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one other one for Greg. Greg, it was my recollection that upon the completion of the 16-well program on your 100% block on the Northwestern Shelf, you'd be in a position to give us some kind of a resource indication. Can you help us out in t
componenttext: And then just one other one for Greg. Greg, it was my recollection that upon the completion of the 16-well program on your 100% block on the Northwestern Shelf, you'd be in a position to give us some kind of a resource indication. Can you help us out in that regard?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. I think I'd rather wait until I get my appraisal program done to do that.
componenttext: Yes, Mark. I think I'd rather wait until I get my appraisal program done to do that.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kate Minyard from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kate Minyard from JPMorgan.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on Brunei. Just given your interest in Block CA-1, I was wondering if you could give us any color on just timing. It looks that the operator is eager to start drilling in a short period of time. I'm just wondering if you had any insi
componenttext: Just a quick question on Brunei. Just given your interest in Block CA-1, I was wondering if you could give us any color on just timing. It looks that the operator is eager to start drilling in a short period of time. I'm just wondering if you had any insight into whether that was early 2011? Or is it a bit too early to tell?

componenttext: Let me talk about Ghana, since you mentioned both. So in Ghana, it's a large block. We see multiple play types on the block, both structural and stratigraphic. headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Hess Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Shamika, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to your hos
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Hess Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Shamika, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Mr. Jay Wilson, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you ever much. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in our Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projection
componenttext:
Thank you ever much. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in our Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Our earnings release was issued this morning and appears on our website, www.hess.com. Today's conference call contains projections and other forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ from those expressed or implied in such statements.
With me today are John Hess, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; Greg Hill, President, Worldwide Exploration and Production; and John Rielly, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
I will now turn the call over to John Hess.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and welcome to our second quarter conference call. I will make a few brief comments, after which John Rielly will review our financial results.Net income for the second quarter of 2010 was $375 million versus $100 million a year ago. Our
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and welcome to our second quarter conference call. I will make a few brief comments, after which John Rielly will review our financial results.
Net income for the second quarter of 2010 was $375 million versus $100 million a year ago. Our results were positively impacted by higher crude oil and natural gas selling prices and lower exploration expense compared to the year-ago quarter.
Exploration and Production earned $488 million. Crude oil and natural gas production averaged 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was 2% above the year-ago period. Higher year-over-year production resulted primarily from increased volumes from the Shenzi Field in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico and the Valhall Field in Norway.
Net production from the Bakken is currently more than 16,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, and we remain on track to exit this year at a net rate of about 20,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. We added three additional rigs during the second quarter and currently have eight rigs dedicated to drilling Bakken wells.
As a result of strong year-to-date production performance, we have raised our full year 2010 production forecast to a range of 405,000 to 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, from our previously forecasted range of 400,000 to 410,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day.
Regarding the recent tragic accident in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, we are deeply saddened by the devastating loss of life, ecological damage to the Gulf Coast and severe economic impact on local communities. While our company believes we have extremely high performance requirements for the safety of drilling operations, we and our industry need to do all we can to learn from this disaster and to take the necessary precautions to ensure such a tragedy never happens again.
The near-term impact of the moratorium on Hess is expected to be relatively minimal. Our only operated rig in the Gulf of Mexico, the Stena Forth, left the Pony #3 location on Green Canyon 469 in June as part of a pre-existing farm-out agreement. We anticipate completing the Pony #3 well as soon as practicable, following the lifting of the moratorium. The drilling of a production well at the Shenzi Field, in which Hess has a 28% interest, was suspended as a result of the moratorium, but this delay is expected to have only a very modest impact on our 2010 production.
In June, we announced our intent to preempt BP on their acquisition of Total's interest in the Valhall and Hod Fields in Norway. Hess will pay $496 million in cash for an additional 7.85% interest in the Valhall Field and 12.5% interest in the Hod Field, adding proved reserves of approximately 45 million barrels of oil equivalent. This preemption, along with the previously announced asset swap with Shell, will result in our share of the Valhall and Hod Fields increasing to 64.05% and 62.5%, respectively. Both transactions are expected to close by the end of the third quarter.
During the second quarter, we made progress in our strategy to grow our global inventory of unconventional resource opportunities. In May, we announced a partnership with Toreador Resources under which Hess will invest up to $65 million in an initial exploration phase and has the option to earn a 50% working interest and become the operator in more than 1 million gross acres in the Paris Basin in France. An initial six-well program will commence in the fourth quarter and continue through 2011.
Yesterday, we announced the acquisition of American Oil & Gas Inc. for 8.6 million shares of Hess common stock. This transaction will add approximately 85,000 net acres in the Williston Basin in North Dakota, build upon Hess' strong land position, leverage our infrastructure and enhance our growth profile in the Bakken oil play. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter.
With regard to exploration, we drilled two wells on our 100% owned Permit WA-390-P in the Northwest Shelf of Australia, resulting in one discovery and one dry hole. We have now drilled 14 wells on the block, resulting in 11 discoveries. We expect to complete our remaining two commitment wells during the third quarter, followed by an appraisal program that will include additional drilling and flow testing of several wells. Commercial discussions with potential partners regarding WA-390-P are ongoing.
In the fourth quarter, we expect to spud exploration wells on our 40% owned BM-S-22 Block in Brazil and our 100% owned Tano Cape Three Points Block in Ghana. In addition, we plan to drill our 100% owned Semai V prospect in Indonesia during the first quarter of 2011.
Turning to Marketing and Refining, we reported a loss of $19 million, an improvement over the year-ago quarter. Refining margins at our HOVENSA joint venture refinery improved from last year's second quarter as a result of higher distillate crack spreads and wider light/heavy crude differentials. This improvement in refining was more than offset by costs associated with the planned turnaround of the FCC and other related units at our Port Redding, New Jersey facility.
Marketing results were better than the year-ago quarter, principally due to improved margins. Although, Retail Marketing gasoline volumes on a per site basis were down about 4%, total convenience store sales were up nearly 7%. In Energy Marketing, oil sales were higher year-over-year, while natural gas and electricity sales were lower.
Capital and exploratory expenditures in the first half of 2010 were $1.8 billion, substantially all of which were related to Exploration and Production activities. For the full year 2010, our capital and exploratory expenditures forecast has increased to $5.5 billion from $4.1 billion. The increase primarily reflects the acquisition of additional interests in the Valhall and Hod Fields from Total, the acquisition of American Oil & Gas, and further appraisal of Permit WA-390-P in Australia.
We are pleased to make these acquisitions that will help us sustain profitable growth in reserves and production. At the same time, we are maintaining our financial strength, which will provide us the ability to fund future investments. 
I will now turn the call over to John Rielly.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare second quarter 2010 results to the first quarter.The corporation generated consolidated net income of $375 million in the second quarter of 2010 compared with $538 million in the firs
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Hello, everyone. In my remarks today, I will compare second quarter 2010 results to the first quarter.
The corporation generated consolidated net income of $375 million in the second quarter of 2010 compared with $538 million in the first quarter.
Turning to Exploration and Production. Exploration and Production operations in the second quarter of 2010 had income of $488 million compared with $551 million in the first quarter. The first quarter results included after-tax income of $58 million, relating to the sale of the corporation's interest in the Jambi Merang field in Indonesia. Excluding the effect of this asset sale, the change in the after-tax components of the results are as follows: Lower selling prices, primarily natural gas, decreased earnings by $13 million; increased exploration expense reduced earnings by $18 million; increased depreciation expense reduced earnings by $11 million; lower cash operating costs increased earnings by $21 million; all other items net to an increase in earnings of $16 million; for an overall decrease in second quarter adjusted earnings of $5 million.
In the second quarter of 2010, our E&P operations were under lifted compared with production, resulting in decreased after-tax income in the quarter of approximately $30 million.
Total production unit costs for the first six months of the year amounted to $27.65 per barrel of oil equivalent. We are reducing our total production unit cost guidance for the full year by $1 per barrel to $28.50 to $30.50 per barrel. E&P cash operating costs are expected to be in the range of $14.50 to $15.50 per barrel, down from the previous guidance of $15 to $16 per barrel. Depreciation, depletion and amortization charges are expected to be in the range of $14 to $15 per barrel, down from $14.50 to $15.50 per barrel.
The E&P effective income tax rate was 43% in the second quarter. For the full year of 2010, we are reducing our E&P effective tax rate guidance to a range of 44% to 48%, down from 47% to 51%.
Turning to Marketing and Refining. Marketing and Refining operations generated a loss of $19 million in the second quarter of 2010 compared with income of $87 million in the first quarter.
Refining operations lost $31 million in the second quarter compared with $56 million in the first quarter. The corporation's share of HOVENSA's results, after income taxes, was a loss of $4 million in the second quarter compared with $52 million in the first quarter, reflecting improved refining margins in the second quarter. Also, the first quarter included turnaround expenses of approximately $20 million, after income taxes, for scheduled maintenance on the FCC unit at HOVENSA.
Port Redding generated a loss of $27 million in the second quarter compared to a loss of $4 million in the first quarter. During the second quarter, this refining facility was shut down for 41 days for a planned turnaround. The turnaround expenses recorded in the second quarter totaled approximately $27 million, after income taxes.
Marketing earnings were $17 million in the second quarter of 2010 compared with $121 million in the first quarter, principally reflecting seasonally lower margins and sales volumes in Energy Marketing operations. Trading activities generated a loss of $5 million in the second quarter compared with income of $22 million in the first quarter.
Turning to Corporate. Net Corporate expenses amounted to $42 million in the second quarter of 2010 compared with $48 million in the first quarter. Net Corporate expenses in the first quarter included an after-tax charge of $7 million for the repurchase of the remaining $116 million of bonds that were scheduled to mature in 2011.
After-tax interest was $52 million in both the second and first quarters.
Turning to cash flow. Net cash provided by operating activities in the second quarter, including a decrease of $39 million from changes in working capital, was $981 million. Repayments of debt were $15 million. Capital expenditures were $901 million. All other items amounted to a decrease in cash of $72 million, resulting in a net decrease in cash and cash equivalents in the second quarter of $7 million.
We had $1,363,000,000 of cash and cash equivalents at June 30, 2010, and $1,362,000,000 at December 31, 2009. Our available revolving credit capacity was $3 billion at June 30, 2010. Total debt was $4,326,000,000 at June 30, 2010, and $4,467,000,000 at December 31, 2009. The corporation's debt-to-capitalization ratio at June 30, 2010, was 22.9% compared with 24.8% at the end of 2009.
This concludes my remarks. We will be happy to answer any questions. I will now turn the call over to the operator.

Clearly, paying cash for acreage, would be interested to hear your views around the flow rates that you'd expect in their acreage because it's a different area to your own. But two separate related questions. One is around gas utilization, I think you have a gas plant nearby, which means you hopefully could get production from AXP. And the second one is a more broad question around lease expiry in your own acreage and in AXP. I understand there might be quite a big lease expiry next year, if you could make some comments on that.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Greg Hill. A couple of comments. First of all, just to give everybody some perspective. So this is 85,000 net acres, as John said, and it's located six miles west of Tioga Gas Plant. So clearly, it's very close to our existing infrastructure. It i
componenttext: This is Greg Hill. A couple of comments. First of all, just to give everybody some perspective. So this is 85,000 net acres, as John said, and it's located six miles west of Tioga Gas Plant. So clearly, it's very close to our existing infrastructure. It is west of the anticline. We've got a lot of drilling to do in there. So we don't really want to comment about flow rates yet. There's only three wells in the block. So we've got a lot more drilling left to do before we're going to update our guidance on production. But clearly, we're excited about the acreage and it will be accretive to our Bakken production profile.

componenttext: I've got a couple of quick ones on the Bakken, and then one on just rigs, if I may. componenttext: Yes, thanks, Doug. So on production reserve this year, be very, very minor because there's just a few wells over there. componenttext: If I may just do a follow up on the cost guidance that John Rielly gave. How much of that is the contribution from the Bakken as you move this forward? And I guess, what's behind my question is you think 80,000 plus within four or five years, what's that going to do to your cost guidance, please?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, let's just talk about this year. From a cost guidance standpoint, clearly, we have higher volumes than we projected earlier in the year. And so obviously, with the costs going over more volumes, it's going to lower our cost per barrel. The B
componenttext: Sure. I mean, let's just talk about this year. From a cost guidance standpoint, clearly, we have higher volumes than we projected earlier in the year. And so obviously, with the costs going over more volumes, it's going to lower our cost per barrel. The Bakken contracting strategy that was put in place also was beneficial to our forecast. So we were able to lower our cost there. Now going forward, obviously it makes sense if you have more volumes with a cost base, it will eventually begin to drive down your cost in any area. But we're not going to project where our costs are going over the next several years.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: But risks are skewed lower, John? Fair? Is it fair to say that the risks are skewed lower?
componenttext: But risks are skewed lower, John? Fair? Is it fair to say that the risks are skewed lower?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct. And again, Greg had mentioned this previously, we have locked in most of our -- probably about 90% of our drilling and completion costs in the Bakken here for the next five years. So one, we've lock in these costs, which we believe are at fa
componenttext: Yes, correct. And again, Greg had mentioned this previously, we have locked in most of our -- probably about 90% of our drilling and completion costs in the Bakken here for the next five years. So one, we've lock in these costs, which we believe are at favorable rates. There's performance incentives in these contracts also to continuing to try to drive down costs as we get more and more familiar with the acreage. And on top of that, we have dedicated crews up there for frac-ing, as well as equipment. So again, we do like our position here in the Bakken.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010

componenttext: And last one for me is just jumping to rig count redeployment, I guess. My understanding was you were due to get the Stena Forth back sometime later this year. What are the plans in terms of redeploying that elsewhere? I'm thinking Egypt may be on the list, but if you could just give us some thoughts around that, that would be great.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So the Stena Forth is in a farm-out to Cairn currently. She'll come back to us sometime in the fourth quarter. And the plan is to move her to the Northern Red Sea to drill a couple wells there. And then depending upon the outcome of the moratorium at the
componenttext: So the Stena Forth is in a farm-out to Cairn currently. She'll come back to us sometime in the fourth quarter. And the plan is to move her to the Northern Red Sea to drill a couple wells there. And then depending upon the outcome of the moratorium at the Gulf of Mexico, she'll either come back to the Gulf of Mexico, mid-year next year, or go to Ghana and drill a follow-up well in Ghana. So that's the plan for the Stena.

componenttext: Greg, I wanted to ask you just kind of high-level strategy question about what's been a very active set of asset deals and company deals that you've done. Where are you in this process now, do you feel? Is this going to be a level of activity that you see yourselves maintaining? Or do you feel like you're arriving at an asset base that you're comfortable with?

componenttext: I mean, we're being very opportunistic. I mean, as we see -- particularly in the Bakken, as we see opportunities that's clearly a core hub for us. As we see profitable opportunities to capitalize on our competitive advantage in the Bakken, we'll entertain those opportunities.

componenttext: I'd say it's a balancing process, Paul.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then a specific one. How long will it be now -- you've given some guidance on Shenzi and Pony, but from the moment the moratorium is lifted, assuming it is, how long would it be now would you expect from that point before you saw first production at b
componenttext: And then a specific one. How long will it be now -- you've given some guidance on Shenzi and Pony, but from the moment the moratorium is lifted, assuming it is, how long would it be now would you expect from that point before you saw first production at both of those two assets?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's a really good question because I think the biggest factor on the uncertainty in Pony or really anything in the Gulf of Mexico is all around the regulatory framework, which the government -- even though the moratorium is going to be lifted i
componenttext: I think that's a really good question because I think the biggest factor on the uncertainty in Pony or really anything in the Gulf of Mexico is all around the regulatory framework, which the government -- even though the moratorium is going to be lifted in November as we understand it. So certainly, as soon as that's lifted, we'll plan to bring a rig back in the Gulf of Mexico. But until there's clarity on that regulatory framework, it's really kind of hard to speculate right now on when timing will or -- whether it will slip or not on things like Pony and some of the developments. So until we get clarity from the government on that framework, I don't really want to speculate on what it means.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of some of the elements that are out there in terms of limitations, let's say, for example, liability cap changing, what would be your perspective on what would be a damaging government policy or preventative government policy against what you th
componenttext: In terms of some of the elements that are out there in terms of limitations, let's say, for example, liability cap changing, what would be your perspective on what would be a damaging government policy or preventative government policy against what you think would be a very reasonable reaction to the disaster?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, I might come in on that one. There's been a lot of numbers speculated by different politicians about what the right cap level is. And some of the things that are being discussed now that we would be supportive of is raising the cap to a $1 bill
componenttext: Yes, Paul, I might come in on that one. There's been a lot of numbers speculated by different politicians about what the right cap level is. And some of the things that are being discussed now that we would be supportive of is raising the cap to a $1 billion where the company that was doing the drilling would be responsible for that $1 billion exposure, with insurance on its side. And then having some kind of cooperative above that, where all of the investors and operators in the Gulf of Mexico would participate in some kind of insurance cooperative. That then would deal with catastrophic spills. So that kind of idea of having a company number going up to, let's say, $1 billion, and then anything in excess of that being a group cooperative is something that we would be supportive of. Things higher than that, I think would be destructive to the competition in the Gulf and wouldn't be in the United States' interest.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Evan Calio of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe a question on the tax rate. I know your lower tax guidance after two quarters trending lower, I presume that's lower international versus 50% type of average. Is there a mix issue? Or can you kind of help us understand the other driver in the lower
componenttext: Maybe a question on the tax rate. I know your lower tax guidance after two quarters trending lower, I presume that's lower international versus 50% type of average. Is there a mix issue? Or can you kind of help us understand the other driver in the lower cost guidance? And this is a sustainable new level beyond kind of the guided period?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll try to help you with that. There's nothing really -- I'm going to say unusual in our tax rate in the first two quarters. So you do have -- you always have mix, you've got the concept of the under lift that I mentioned. So it's not a big portion
componenttext: Sure, I'll try to help you with that. There's nothing really -- I'm going to say unusual in our tax rate in the first two quarters. So you do have -- you always have mix, you've got the concept of the under lift that I mentioned. So it's not a big portion, but Libya is a bit under lifted here in this quarter. But what ends up happening with our forecast is the higher commodity price that you have brings in more pretax income from other areas outside of Libya. And so Libya becomes a smaller percentage of our overall pretax income. And therefore, the effective rate becomes lower just when you put the portfolio together, so you have that coming about. So with these higher commodity prices, we've been forecasting lower rate and that's why we're bringing down the guidance. Now going out, I mean, again, we will give you the guidance for next year on our January call. But the one thing you do see, our guidance is still higher for the second half of the year as compared to the first half of the year. And some of the results of that is our Valhall swaps. So we will be getting more interest in Valhall. It's a higher rate. And so that will be bringing up our rate in the second half of the year, and obviously, then we'll have a higher interest in Valhall going into 2011. So that can cause that rate again to be a little higher than where it is right now.

componenttext: It's a bit of a follow up on some of the prior Gulf of Mexico exposure. But I mean, is your insurance policies, as you think about the Gulf of Mexico, is that renegotiated on an annual basis? Or is it kind of mid-year renegotiation process?

componenttext: The government has to be clear on what its regulations are going to be. And then the insurance companies would respond in time. But the kind of number I talked about before, $1 billion is pretty close to one that we can handle right now.

componenttextpreview: Greg, I wonder if you could just give us a little bit of an overall update on the Bakken in terms of EURs, well costs? And in particular, just address for me whether you're continuing to develop on a 1,280-acre spacing mode?
componenttext: Greg, I wonder if you could just give us a little bit of an overall update on the Bakken in terms of EURs, well costs? And in particular, just address for me whether you're continuing to develop on a 1,280-acre spacing mode?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are, Mark. So let me take the first bit of that. We currently are developing on the 1,280-acre spacing mode using dual laterals. So that gives you an effective acreage of 430, if you think about how the dual laterals are configured. Still early da
componenttext: Yes, we are, Mark. So let me take the first bit of that. We currently are developing on the 1,280-acre spacing mode using dual laterals. So that gives you an effective acreage of 430, if you think about how the dual laterals are configured. Still early days in the dual laterals, but our costs are averaging $10 million to $11 million each. EURs are 1 million barrels per well and our 30-day average IP rates around the order of 400 to 500 barrels per lateral, so you effectively double that for a dual lateral.

componenttext: No, that particular platform is just all part of production maintenance. That's all it is. Now we did acquire PM301 to the south, and we're working with PETRONAS to try and bring PM301 into the JDA infrastructure.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So again our plans in the Marcellus, just to remind everyone, we've got about 92,000 acres in the Marcellus. That's split between Newfield and ourselves. Our plans are to drill five wells on the Newfield acreage in 2010, drill five wells on the Hess
componenttext: Yes. So again our plans in the Marcellus, just to remind everyone, we've got about 92,000 acres in the Marcellus. That's split between Newfield and ourselves. Our plans are to drill five wells on the Newfield acreage in 2010, drill five wells on the Hess acreage in 2010. And we've got permits for those, seven of those wells are going to be in the DRBC. The remainder will be in the Susquehanna River basin. So we've got all the permits we need, and we will plan to finish our drilling before the end of the year.

componenttext: The end of 2010?

headline: Hess Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
